Absalom was proud of his hair, The Sages taught Absalom rebelled due to his hair, as it is stated: there was none as Absalom for his beauty; And when he shaved his head, as it was at every year’s end that he shaved it; because the hair was heavy on him, therefore he shaved it, and he weighed the hair of his head at two hundred shekels, by the king’s stone” taught: A stone with which the people of Tiberias and the people of Tzippori weigh

therefore, he was hung by his hair, as it is stated “And Absalom chanced to meet the servants of David. And Absalom was riding upon his mule, and the mule went under the thick boughs of a great terebinth, and his head caught hold of the terebinth, and he was taken up between the heaven and the earth; and the mule that was under him went on” took a sword [ safseira ] and wanted to cut his hair The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: At that moment, the netherworld opened beneath him

“And the king was much moved, and went up to the chamber over the gate, and wept; and as he went about he said: O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! Would I had died in your place, O Absalom, my son, my son” “And the king covered his face, and the king cried with a loud voice: O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son” Why these eight “my son” Seven which he raised him up from the seven chambers of Gehenna. And the other, some say that brought head close to body, and some say that brought to the World-to-Come.

“Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and reared up for himself What did take? Reish Lakish says: He engaged in a bad transaction for himself “The pillar, which is in the king’s valley [ be’emek hammelekh ].” Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa says: in the deep [ amukka ] counsel of the King [ melekh ] of the universe,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rather, "And he called." Teaches that our father Abraham called the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, with the mouth of every passerby. How so? After they ate and drank, they stood to bless. He said to them: Did you eat from what is mine? You ate from what belongs to the God of the world! Give thanks, praise, and bless to the One who spoke and the world came into being.
"And Judah saw her and he thought her to be a prostitute, for she had covered her face." Because she covered her face, he thought her to be a prostitute?!

Rabbi Elazar said: "She covered her face in her father-in-law's house." As Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said in the name of Rabbi Yonatan: "Every bride who is modest in her father-in-law's house - she merits that kings and prophets come from her. From where do we derive this? From Tamar. Prophets - as it is written: 'The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz.' Kings - from David." And Rabbi Levi said: "This matter is a tradition handed down to us from our ancestors: Amoz and Amatzyah were brothers."
"She finds." "She is found." What does he want with "she is found"? Rabbi Elazar said: After her signs were found, Samael came and distanced them, then Gabriel came and brought them close.

That is as it is written: "For the conductor, upon the silent dove, distant ones, a michtam of David." Rabbi Yochanan said: From the moment its signs distanced themselves, it became like a silent dove. "A michtam of David": that David emerged from it, for he was humble and simple towards all. Another explanation: "Michtam" - that his strike was wondrous, as he was born circumcised. Another explanation: "Michtam" - just as in his youth he humbled himself before one greater than him to learn Torah, so too in his greatness.

"And she sent to her mother-in-law, saying, 'To the man to whom these belong, I am pregnant.' And say to him from the matter! Rav Zutra bar Tobiah said in the name of Rav, and some say in the name of Rav Hana bar Bizna said in the name of Rabbi Shimon Chasida, and some say in the name of Rabbi Yochanan in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai: It is better for a person to throw himself into a fiery furnace than to shame his fellow in public. From where do we derive this? From the date palm."

"The pit, please." Rabbi Ḥama son of Rabbi Ḥanina said: With 'the pit,' he was honest to his father - with 'the pit,' they sold him. With 'the pit,' he was honest: 'The pit is your son's tunic.' With 'the pit,' they sold him: 'To whom is the pit.'"
"Na." There is no "na" except as a language of difficulty. She said to him: 'With difficulty from you, recognize the face of your Creator, and do not hide your eyes from me.'

"And Judah recognized and said, 'She is more righteous than I.' That is what Rav Hanin bar Bizna said in the name of Rabbi Shimon Chasida: Anyone who sanctifies the name of Heaven in secret - he merits, and they add to him one letter from the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is written: 'The testimony of Joseph he set.'"

Judah who sanctified the name of Heaven in public - he merited and was called by the name of the Holy One, blessed be He. Once he acknowledged and said, "Righteousness is from me," a heavenly voice emerged and said: "You have saved Tamar and her two sons from the fire - by your merit, I save three of your sons from the fire." Who are they? Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah.
"Righteousness from me." From where did he know? A heavenly voice emerged and said: "From me came forth the ashamed."

"And not add more to her knowledge." Shmuel the Elder said in the name of Shmuel bar Ammi: Once she knew it - she never ceased from it. It is written here: "And not add more to her knowledge," and it is written there: "A loud voice and does not add."

Talmudic text: Avshalom nitga'ah bis'aro v'chu. Tanu Rabbanan: Avshalom bis'aro marad, shene'emar: "u'ch'Avshalom lo hayah ish yafeh v'cho." u'v'galcho et rosho v'hayah miketz yamim layamim asher yegale'ach ki kaveid alav v'gilcho v'shakal et se'ar rosho matayim sh'kalim b'even hammelech. Tanah: even she'anshei Teverya v'anshei Tzipori shoklim bah. English translation: Avshalom was proud of his hair, as it is stated: "And in all Israel there was none to be so much praised as Avshalom for his beauty." And when he shaved his head at the end of every year, for it was heavy on him, he would weigh the hair of his head, and it amounted to two hundred shekels by the king's weight. It was taught: the stone that the men of Teverya and the men of Tzipori would weigh with.

Therefore, he was hanged by his hair, as it is stated: "And Absalom called before David's servants, and Absalom rode upon the mule, and the mule came under the thick branches of a great terebinth, and his head caught hold of the terebinth, and he was suspended between the heaven and the earth, and the mule that was under him passed by." Shikl Sapsera sought to resolve it. It was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: At that moment, the netherworld split open beneath him.

The king was agitated and went up to the upper chamber of the gate and wept, and thus he said as he went, "O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! Would I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!" And the king covered his face and cried out with a loud voice, "O my son Absalom, Absalom, my son, my son!" Those Talmudic scholars say, "Why 'my son' seven times? Because he was punished with seven punishments in Gehenna. And others say: he brought his head close to his body, and others say: he brought him to the world to come.

"And Avshalom took and set up for himself in his lifetime." What is meant by "took"? Reish Lakish said: that he took an evil acquisition for himself. "The pillar that is in the King's Valley, etc." Rabbi Chanina bar Papa said: with deep counsel of the eternal King.

sentences.text: אֶלָּא ״וַיַּקְרִיא״. מְלַמֵּד שֶׁהִקְרִיא אַבְרָהָם אָבִינוּ לִשְׁמוֹ שֶׁל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא בְּפֶה כׇּל עוֹבֵר וָשָׁב. כֵּיצַד? לְאַחַר שֶׁאָכְלוּ וְשָׁתוּ, עָמְדוּ לְבָרְכוֹ. אָמַר לָהֶם: וְכִי מִשֶּׁלִּי אֲכַלְתֶּם? מִשֶּׁל אֱלֹהֵי עוֹלָם אֲכַלְתֶּם! הוֹדוּ וְשַׁבְּחוּ וּבָרְכוּ לְמִי שֶׁאָמַר וְהָיָה הָעוֹלָם.
sentences.human_translation: rather vayyakri , and he caused to call. teaches that Abraham our forefather caused the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to be called in the mouth of all passersby. How so? After ate and drank, they arose to bless him. He said to them: But did you eat from mine? you ate from the God of the world. you thank and praise and bless the One Who spoke and the world was
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rather, "And he called." Teaches that our father Abraham called the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, with the mouth of every passerby. How so? After they ate and drank, they stood to bless. He said to them: Did you eat from what is mine? You ate from what belongs to the God of the world! Give thanks, praise, and bless to the One who spoke and the world came into being.

sentences.text: ״וַיִּרְאֶהָ יְהוּדָה וַיַּחְשְׁבֶהָ לְזוֹנָה כִּי כִסְּתָה פָּנֶיהָ״. מִשּׁוּם דְּכִסְּתָה פָּנֶיהָ, חַשְּׁבַהּ לְזוֹנָה?!
sentences.human_translation: “When Judah saw her, he thought her to be a prostitute, for she had covered her face” Because she had covered her face he thought her to be a prostitute?
sentences.llm_translation: "And Judah saw her and he thought her to be a prostitute, for she had covered her face." Because she covered her face, he thought her to be a prostitute?!

sentences.text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: שֶׁכִּסְּתָה פָּנֶיהָ בְּבֵית חָמִיהָ. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: כׇּל כַּלָּה שֶׁהִיא צְנוּעָה בְּבֵית חָמִיהָ — זוֹכָה וְיוֹצְאִין מִמֶּנָּה מְלָכִים וּנְבִיאִים. מְנָלַן — מִתָּמָר. נְבִיאִים — דִּכְתִיב: ״חֲזוֹן יְשַׁעְיָהוּ בֶן אָמוֹץ״. מְלָכִים — מִדָּוִד. וְאָמַר רַבִּי לֵוִי: דָּבָר זֶה מָסוֹרֶת בְּיָדֵינוּ מֵאֲבוֹתֵינוּ: אָמוֹץ וַאֲמַצְיָה — אַחִים הֲווֹ.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Elazar says: that covered her face in the home of her father-in-law, As Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says Rabbi Yonatan says: Any daughter-in-law who is modest in the house of her father-in-law merits that kings and prophets emerge from her. From where do we From Tamar. Prophets as it is written: “The vision of Isaiah, the son of Amoz” Kings from David. And Rabbi Levi says: This matter is a tradition we from our ancestors: Amoz, and Amaziah, were brothers.
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: "She covered her face in her father-in-law's house." As Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said in the name of Rabbi Yonatan: "Every bride who is modest in her father-in-law's house - she merits that kings and prophets come from her. From where do we derive this? From Tamar. Prophets - as it is written: 'The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz.' Kings - from David." And Rabbi Levi said: "This matter is a tradition handed down to us from our ancestors: Amoz and Amatzyah were brothers."

sentences.text: ״הִיא מוּצֵאת״. ״הִיא מִיתּוֹצֵאת״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: לְאַחַר שֶׁנִּמְצְאוּ סִימָנֶיהָ בָּא סַמָּאֵל וְרִיחֲקָן, בָּא גַּבְרִיאֵל וְקֵירְבָן.
sentences.human_translation: “When she was brought forth [ mutzet ], It should have When she was mitutzet . Rabbi Elazar says: After her signs, were brought out, Samael came and distanced them Gabriel came and moved closer
sentences.llm_translation: "She finds." "She is found." What does he want with "she is found"? Rabbi Elazar said: After her signs were found, Samael came and distanced them, then Gabriel came and brought them close.

sentences.text: הַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב: ״לִמְנַצֵּחַ עַל יוֹנַת אֵלֶם רְחוֹקִים לְדָוִד מִכְתָּם״, אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מִשָּׁעָה שֶׁנִּתְרַחֲקוּ סִימָנֶיהָ נַעֲשֵׂית כְּיוֹנָה אִילֶּמֶת. ״לְדָוִד מִכְתָּם״: שֶׁיָּצָא מִמֶּנָּה דָּוִד, שֶׁהָיָה מָךְ וְתָם לַכֹּל. דָּבָר אַחֵר: ״מִכְתָּם״ — שֶׁהָיְתָה מַכָּתוֹ תַּמָּה, שֶׁנּוֹלַד כְּשֶׁהוּא מָהוּל. דָּבָר אַחֵר: ״מִכְתָּם״ — כְּשֵׁם שֶׁבְּקַטְנוּתוֹ הִקְטִין עַצְמוֹ אֵצֶל מִי שֶׁגָּדוֹל מִמֶּנּוּ לִלְמוֹד תּוֹרָה, כָּךְ בִּגְדוּלָּתוֹ.
sentences.human_translation: This is as it is written: “For the leader, upon yonat eilem reḥokim , a psalm [ mikhtam ] of David” Rabbi Yoḥanan says From the moment that her signs were distanced [ reḥokim ], she became like a mute dove [ yona illemet ]. “a psalm [ mikhtam ] of David” from whom David emerged, as he was modest [ makh ] and flawless [ tam ] with everyone. Alternatively, mikhtam that makkato , was complete [ tama ], that was born circumcised. Alternatively, mikhtam just as in his youth made himself small in front of one who was greater than him to learn Torah so too, when he became great
sentences.llm_translation: That is as it is written: "For the conductor, upon the silent dove, distant ones, a michtam of David." Rabbi Yochanan said: From the moment its signs distanced themselves, it became like a silent dove. "A michtam of David": that David emerged from it, for he was humble and simple towards all. Another explanation: "Michtam" - that his strike was wondrous, as he was born circumcised. Another explanation: "Michtam" - just as in his youth he humbled himself before one greater than him to learn Torah, so too in his greatness.

sentences.text: ״וְהִיא שָׁלְחָה אֶל חָמִיהָ לֵאמֹר לְאִישׁ אֲשֶׁר אֵלֶּה לּוֹ אָנֹכִי הָרָה״. וְתֵימָא לֵיהּ מֵימָר! אָמַר רַב זוּטְרָא בַּר טוֹבִיָּה אָמַר רַב, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ אָמַר רַב חָנָא בַּר בִּיזְנָא אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן חֲסִידָא, וְאָמְרִי לָהּ אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַי: נוֹחַ לוֹ לָאָדָם שֶׁיַּפִּיל עַצְמוֹ לְתוֹךְ כִּבְשַׁן הָאֵשׁ, וְאַל יַלְבִּין פְּנֵי חֲבֵירוֹ בָּרַבִּים. מְנָלַן — מִתָּמָר.
sentences.human_translation: “She sent to her father-in-law, saying: By the man whose these are, am I with child” And let her say to him Rav Zutra bar Tuviyya says Rav says, and some say Rav Ḥana bar Bizna says Rabbi Shimon Ḥasida says, and some say Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai: It is more amenable for a person to throw himself into a fiery furnace and not humiliate another in public. From where do we From Tamar,
sentences.llm_translation: "And she sent to her mother-in-law, saying, 'To the man to whom these belong, I am pregnant.' And say to him from the matter! Rav Zutra bar Tobiah said in the name of Rav, and some say in the name of Rav Hana bar Bizna said in the name of Rabbi Shimon Chasida, and some say in the name of Rabbi Yochanan in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai: It is better for a person to throw himself into a fiery furnace than to shame his fellow in public. From where do we derive this? From the date palm."

sentences.text: ״הַכֶּר נָא״. אָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: בְּ״הַכֶּר״ בִּישֵּׂר לְאָבִיו — בְּ״הַכֶּר״ בִּישְּׂרוּהוּ. בְּ״הַכֶּר״ בִּישֵּׂר: ״הַכֶּר נָא הַכְּתֹנֶת בִּנְךָ הִיא״. בְּ״הַכֶּר״ בִּישְּׂרוּהוּ: ״הַכֶּר נָא לְמִי״.
sentences.human_translation: Discern, please, Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: With discern informed his father with discern they informed With discern he informed Discern now whether it is your son’s coat With discern they informed him: Discern, please, whose are
sentences.llm_translation: "The pit, please." Rabbi Ḥama son of Rabbi Ḥanina said: With 'the pit,' he was honest to his father - with 'the pit,' they sold him. With 'the pit,' he was honest: 'The pit is your son's tunic.' With 'the pit,' they sold him: 'To whom is the pit.'"

sentences.text: ״נָא״. אֵין ״נָא״ אֶלָּא לְשׁוֹן בַּקָּשָׁה. אָמְרָה לֵיהּ: בְּבַקָּשָׁה מִמְּךָ, הַכֵּר פְּנֵי בּוֹרַאֲךָ וְאַל תַּעֲלִים עֵינֶיךָ מִמֶּנִּי.
sentences.human_translation: please [ na ].” na nothing other a language of request. She said to him: I request of you: Discern the image of your Creator and do not avert your eyes from me.
sentences.llm_translation: "Na." There is no "na" except as a language of difficulty. She said to him: 'With difficulty from you, recognize the face of your Creator, and do not hide your eyes from me.'

sentences.text: ״וַיַּכֵּר יְהוּדָה וַיֹּאמֶר צָדְקָה מִמֶּנִּי״. הַיְינוּ דְּאָמַר רַב חָנִין בַּר בִּיזְנָא אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן חֲסִידָא: יוֹסֵף שֶׁקִּדֵּשׁ שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם בַּסֵּתֶר — זָכָה וְהוֹסִיפוּ לוֹ אוֹת אַחַת מִשְּׁמוֹ שֶׁל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא, דִּכְתִיב: ״עֵדוּת בִּיהוֹסֵף שָׂמוֹ״.
sentences.human_translation: “And Judah acknowledged them, and said: She is more righteous than I; This is as Rav Ḥanin bar Bizna says Rabbi Shimon Ḥasida says: Joseph, who sanctified the name of Heaven in private merited that one letter from the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He, was added to his as it is written: “He appointed it in Joseph [ bihosef ] for a testimony in his name,
sentences.llm_translation: "And Judah recognized and said, 'She is more righteous than I.' That is what Rav Hanin bar Bizna said in the name of Rabbi Shimon Chasida: Anyone who sanctifies the name of Heaven in secret - he merits, and they add to him one letter from the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is written: 'The testimony of Joseph he set.'"

sentences.text: יְהוּדָה שֶׁקִּדֵּשׁ שֵׁם שָׁמַיִם בְּפַרְהֶסְיָא — זָכָה וְנִקְרָא כּוּלּוֹ עַל שְׁמוֹ שֶׁל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא. כֵּיוָן שֶׁהוֹדָה וְאָמַר ״צָדְקָה מִמֶּנִּי״, יָצְתָה בַּת קוֹל וְאָמְרָה: אַתָּה הִצַּלְתָּ תָּמָר וּשְׁנֵי בָּנֶיהָ מִן הָאוּר — חַיֶּיךָ שֶׁאֲנִי מַצִּיל בִּזְכוּתְךָ שְׁלֹשָׁה מִבָּנֶיךָ מִן הָאוּר. מַאן נִינְהוּ — חֲנַנְיָה מִישָׁאֵל וַעֲזַרְיָה.
sentences.human_translation: Judah, who sanctified the name of Heaven in public, merited that his entire is called by the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He, When he confessed and said: “She is more righteous than I,” a Divine Voice went forth and said: You saved Tamar and her two children from the fire. your life, in your merit, I will save three of your children from the fire. who are they? Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah
sentences.llm_translation: Judah who sanctified the name of Heaven in public - he merited and was called by the name of the Holy One, blessed be He. Once he acknowledged and said, "Righteousness is from me," a heavenly voice emerged and said: "You have saved Tamar and her two sons from the fire - by your merit, I save three of your sons from the fire." Who are they? Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah.

sentences.text: ״צָדְקָה מִמֶּנִּי״. מְנָא יָדַע? יָצְתָה בַּת קוֹל וְאָמְרָה: מִמֶּנִּי יָצְאוּ כְּבוּשִׁים.
sentences.human_translation: “She is more righteous than I [ mimmenni ].” From where did he know A Divine Voice went forth and said: From Me these hidden emerged,
sentences.llm_translation: "Righteousness from me." From where did he know? A heavenly voice emerged and said: "From me came forth the ashamed."

sentences.text: ״וְלֹא יָסַף עוֹד לְדַעְתָּה״. אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל סָבָא חֲמוּהּ דְּרַב שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר אַמֵּי מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַב שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר אַמֵּי: כֵּיוָן שֶׁיְּדָעָהּ — שׁוּב לֹא פָּסַק מִמֶּנָּה. כְּתִיב הָכָא: ״וְלֹא יָסַף עוֹד לְדַעְתָּה״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם: ״קוֹל גָּדוֹל וְלֹא יָסָף״.
sentences.human_translation: “And he knew her [ leda’atah ] again no more [ velo yasaf ],” Shmuel the Elder, father-in-law of Rav Shmuel bar Ami, says in the name of Rav Shmuel bar Ami: once he knew her he did not desist from her again, it is written here: “ Velo yasaf od leda’atah ,” and it is written there with a great voice and it went on no more [ velo yasaf ]”
sentences.llm_translation: "And not add more to her knowledge." Shmuel the Elder said in the name of Shmuel bar Ammi: Once she knew it - she never ceased from it. It is written here: "And not add more to her knowledge," and it is written there: "A loud voice and does not add."

sentences.text: אַבְשָׁלוֹם נִתְגָּאָה בִּשְׂעָרוֹ וְכוּ׳. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אַבְשָׁלוֹם בִּשְׂעָרוֹ מָרַד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּכְאַבְשָׁלוֹם לֹא הָיָה אִישׁ יָפֶה וְגוֹ׳. וּבְגַלְּחוֹ אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ וְהָיָה מִקֵּץ יָמִים לַיָּמִים אֲשֶׁר יְגַלֵּחַ כִּי כָבֵד עָלָיו וְגִלְּחוֹ וְשָׁקַל אֶת שְׂעַר רֹאשׁוֹ מָאתַיִם שְׁקָלִים בְּאֶבֶן הַמֶּלֶךְ״. תָּנָא: אֶבֶן שֶׁאַנְשֵׁי טְבֶרְיָא וְאַנְשֵׁי צִיפּוֹרִי שׁוֹקְלִים בָּהּ.
sentences.human_translation: Absalom was proud of his hair, The Sages taught Absalom rebelled due to his hair, as it is stated: there was none as Absalom for his beauty; And when he shaved his head, as it was at every year’s end that he shaved it; because the hair was heavy on him, therefore he shaved it, and he weighed the hair of his head at two hundred shekels, by the king’s stone” taught: A stone with which the people of Tiberias and the people of Tzippori weigh
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: Avshalom nitga'ah bis'aro v'chu. Tanu Rabbanan: Avshalom bis'aro marad, shene'emar: "u'ch'Avshalom lo hayah ish yafeh v'cho." u'v'galcho et rosho v'hayah miketz yamim layamim asher yegale'ach ki kaveid alav v'gilcho v'shakal et se'ar rosho matayim sh'kalim b'even hammelech. Tanah: even she'anshei Teverya v'anshei Tzipori shoklim bah. English translation: Avshalom was proud of his hair, as it is stated: "And in all Israel there was none to be so much praised as Avshalom for his beauty." And when he shaved his head at the end of every year, for it was heavy on him, he would weigh the hair of his head, and it amounted to two hundred shekels by the king's weight. It was taught: the stone that the men of Teverya and the men of Tzipori would weigh with.

sentences.text: לְפִיכָךְ נִתְלָה בִּשְׂעָרוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיִּקְרָא אַבְשָׁלוֹם לִפְנֵי עַבְדֵי דָוִד וְאַבְשָׁלוֹם רֹכֵב עַל הַפֶּרֶד וַיָּבֹא הַפֶּרֶד תַּחַת שׂוֹבֶךְ הָאֵלָה הַגְּדוֹלָה וַיֶּחֱזַק רֹאשׁוֹ בָאֵלָה וַיֻּתַּן בֵּין הַשָּׁמַיִם וּבֵין הָאָרֶץ וְהַפֶּרֶד אֲשֶׁר תַּחְתָּיו עָבָר״. שְׁקַל סַפְסִירָא בְּעָא לְמִיפְסְקֵיהּ. תָּנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה נִבְקַע שְׁאוֹל מִתַּחְתָּיו.
sentences.human_translation: therefore, he was hung by his hair, as it is stated “And Absalom chanced to meet the servants of David. And Absalom was riding upon his mule, and the mule went under the thick boughs of a great terebinth, and his head caught hold of the terebinth, and he was taken up between the heaven and the earth; and the mule that was under him went on” took a sword [ safseira ] and wanted to cut his hair The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: At that moment, the netherworld opened beneath him
sentences.llm_translation: Therefore, he was hanged by his hair, as it is stated: "And Absalom called before David's servants, and Absalom rode upon the mule, and the mule came under the thick branches of a great terebinth, and his head caught hold of the terebinth, and he was suspended between the heaven and the earth, and the mule that was under him passed by." Shikl Sapsera sought to resolve it. It was taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael: At that moment, the netherworld split open beneath him.

sentences.text: ״וַיִּרְגַּז הַמֶּלֶךְ וַיַּעַל עַל עֲלִיַּית הַשַּׁעַר וַיֵּבְךְּ וְכֹה אָמַר בְּלֶכְתּוֹ בְּנִי אַבְשָׁלוֹם בְּנִי בְנִי אַבְשָׁלוֹם מִי יִתֵּן מוּתִי אֲנִי תַחְתֶּיךָ אַבְשָׁלוֹם בְּנִי בְנִי. וְהַמֶּלֶךְ לָאַט אֶת פָּנָיו וַיִּזְעַק הַמֶּלֶךְ קוֹל גָּדוֹל בְּנִי אַבְשָׁלוֹם אַבְשָׁלוֹם בְּנִי בְנִי״. הָנֵי תְּמָנְיָא ״בְּנִי״ לְמָה? שִׁבְעָה דְּאַסְּקֵיהּ מִשִּׁבְעָה מְדוֹרֵי גֵיהִנָּם, וְאִידַּךְ, אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי: דְּקָרֵיב רֵישֵׁיהּ לְגַבֵּי גוּפֵיהּ, וְאִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי: דְּאַיְיתֵיהּ לְעָלְמָא דְּאָתֵי.
sentences.human_translation: “And the king was much moved, and went up to the chamber over the gate, and wept; and as he went about he said: O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! Would I had died in your place, O Absalom, my son, my son” “And the king covered his face, and the king cried with a loud voice: O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son” Why these eight “my son” Seven which he raised him up from the seven chambers of Gehenna. And the other, some say that brought head close to body, and some say that brought to the World-to-Come.
sentences.llm_translation: The king was agitated and went up to the upper chamber of the gate and wept, and thus he said as he went, "O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! Would I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!" And the king covered his face and cried out with a loud voice, "O my son Absalom, Absalom, my son, my son!" Those Talmudic scholars say, "Why 'my son' seven times? Because he was punished with seven punishments in Gehenna. And others say: he brought his head close to his body, and others say: he brought him to the world to come.

sentences.text: ״וְאַבְשָׁלוֹם לָקַח וַיַּצֶּב לוֹ בְחַיָּיו״. מַאי ״לָקַח״? אָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: שֶׁלָּקַח מִקָּח רַע לְעַצְמוֹ. ״אֶת מַצֶּבֶת אֲשֶׁר בְּעֵמֶק הַמֶּלֶךְ וְגוֹ׳״, אָמַר רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בַּר פָּפָּא: בְּעֵצָה עֲמוּקָּה שֶׁל מַלְכּוֹ שֶׁל עוֹלָם,
sentences.human_translation: “Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and reared up for himself What did take? Reish Lakish says: He engaged in a bad transaction for himself “The pillar, which is in the king’s valley [ be’emek hammelekh ].” Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa says: in the deep [ amukka ] counsel of the King [ melekh ] of the universe,
sentences.llm_translation: "And Avshalom took and set up for himself in his lifetime." What is meant by "took"? Reish Lakish said: that he took an evil acquisition for himself. "The pillar that is in the King's Valley, etc." Rabbi Chanina bar Papa said: with deep counsel of the eternal King.

text: דִּכְתִיב: ״הִנְנִי מֵקִים עָלֶיךָ רָעָה מִבֵּיתֶךָ״. כַּיּוֹצֵא בַּדָּבָר אַתָּה אוֹמֵר: ״וַיִּשְׁלָחֵהוּ מֵעֵמֶק חֶבְרוֹן״, אָמַר רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בַּר פָּפָּא: בְּעֵצָה עֲמוּקָּה שֶׁל אוֹתוֹ צַדִּיק שֶׁקָּבוּר בְּחֶבְרוֹן, דִּכְתִיב: ״יָדֹעַ תֵּדַע כִּי גֵר יִהְיֶה זַרְעֲךָ״.

״כִּי אָמַר אֵין לִי בֵן״. וְלָא הֲווֹ לֵיהּ בְּנֵי? וְהָכְתִיב: ״וַיִּוָּלְדוּ לְאַבְשָׁלוֹם שְׁלֹשָׁה בָּנִים וּבַת אַחַת״! אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בַּר אַבְדִּימִי: שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה לוֹ בֵּן הָגוּן לַמַּלְכוּת. רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר, גְּמִירִי: כׇּל הַשּׂוֹרֵף תְּבוּאָתוֹ שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ, אֵינוֹ מַנִּיחַ בֵּן לְיוֹרְשׁוֹ. וְאִיהוּ קַלְיַיהּ לִדְיוֹאָב, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֹּאמֶר אֶל עֲבָדָיו רְאוּ חֶלְקַת יוֹאָב אֶל יָדִי וְלוֹ שָׁם שְׂעֹרִים לְכוּ וְהַצִּיתוּהָ בָאֵשׁ וַיַּצִּיתוּ עַבְדֵי אַבְשָׁלוֹם אֶת הַחֶלְקָה בָּאֵשׁ״.
וְכֵן לְעִנְיַן הַטּוֹבָה מִרְיָם וְכוּ׳. מִי דָּמֵי? הָתָם — חֲדָא שַׁעְתָּא, הָכָא — שִׁבְעָה יוֹמֵי! אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, אֵימָא: וּלְעִנְיַן הַטּוֹבָה אֵינוֹ כֵּן.

אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: הָא ״וְכֵן לְעִנְיַן הַטּוֹבָה״ קָתָנֵי! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא, הָכִי קָתָנֵי: וְכֵן לְעִנְיַן הַטּוֹבָה, דִּבְאוֹתָהּ מִדָּה, וּלְעוֹלָם מִדָּה טוֹבָה מְרוּבָּה מִמִּדַּת פּוּרְעָנוּת.

״וַתֵּתַצַּב אֲחוֹתוֹ מֵרָחוֹק״, אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: פָּסוּק זֶה כּוּלּוֹ עַל שֵׁם שְׁכִינָה נֶאֱמַר: ״וַתֵּתַצַּב״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיָּבֹא ה׳ וַיִּתְיַצַּב וְגוֹ׳״. ״אֲחוֹתוֹ״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״אֱמֹר לַחׇכְמָה אֲחוֹתִי אָתְּ״. ״מֵרָחוֹק״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״מֵרָחוֹק ה׳ נִרְאָה לִי״. ״לָדַעַת״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי אֵל דֵּעוֹת ה׳״. ״מָה״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״מַה ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ שֹׁאֵל מֵעִמָּךְ״. ״יֵּעָשֶׂה״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי לֹא יַעֲשֶׂה ה׳ אֱלֹהִים דָּבָר״. ״לוֹ״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֹּאמֶר לוֹ ה׳ שָׁלוֹם״.

״וַיָּקׇם מֶלֶךְ חָדָשׁ וְגוֹ׳״. רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, חַד אָמַר: חָדָשׁ מַמָּשׁ, וְחַד אָמַר: שֶׁנִּתְחַדְּשׁוּ גְּזֵירוֹתָיו. מַאן דְּאָמַר חָדָשׁ מַמָּשׁ — דִּכְתִיב ״חָדָשׁ״, וּמַאן דְּאָמַר שֶׁנִּתְחַדְּשׁוּ גְּזֵירוֹתָיו, דְּלָא כְּתִיב ״וַיָּמׇת וַיִּמְלוֹךְ״. ״אֲשֶׁר לֹא יָדַע אֶת יוֹסֵף״, דַּהֲוָה דָּמֵי כְּמַאן דְּלָא יָדַע לֵיהּ כְּלָל.

״וַיֹּאמֶר אֶל עַמּוֹ הִנֵּה עַם בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״. תָּנָא: הוּא הִתְחִיל בְּעֵצָה תְּחִילָּה לְפִיכָךְ לָקָה תְּחִילָּה. הוּא הִתְחִיל בְּעֵצָה תְּחִילָּה — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֹּאמֶר אֶל עַמּוֹ״, לְפִיכָךְ לָקָה תְּחִילָּה — כְּדִכְתִיב: ״וּבְכָה וּבְעַמְּךָ וּבְכׇל עֲבָדֶיךָ״.
״הָבָה נִתְחַכְּמָה לוֹ״. ״לָהֶם״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! אָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: בֹּאוּ וְנֶחְכַּם לְמוֹשִׁיעָן שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל —
בַּמֶּה נְדוּנֵם? נְדוּנֵם בָּאֵשׁ — כְּתִיב: ״כִּי הִנֵּה ה׳ בָּאֵשׁ יָבֹא״, וּכְתִיב: ״כִּי בָאֵשׁ ה׳ נִשְׁפָּט וְגוֹ׳״. בְּחֶרֶב — כְּתִיב: [״וּבְחַרְבּוֹ אֶת כׇּל בָּשָׂר״].

אֶלָּא בּוֹאוּ וּנְדוּנֵם בַּמַּיִם, שֶׁכְּבָר נִשְׁבַּע הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא שֶׁאֵינוֹ מֵבִיא מַבּוּל לָעוֹלָם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי מֵי נֹחַ זֹאת לִי וְגוֹ׳״. וְהֵן אֵינָן יוֹדְעִין שֶׁעַל כׇּל הָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ אֵינוֹ מֵבִיא, אֲבָל עַל אוּמָּה אַחַת הוּא מֵבִיא.

אִי נָמֵי: הוּא אֵינוֹ מֵבִיא, אֲבָל הֵן בָּאִין וְנוֹפְלִין בְּתוֹכוֹ. וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וּמִצְרַיִם נָסִים לִקְרָאתוֹ״. וְהַיְינוּ דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״כִּי בַדָּבָר אֲשֶׁר זָדוּ עֲלֵיהֶם״ — בִּקְדֵירָה שֶׁבִּישְּׁלוּ, בָּהּ נִתְבַּשְּׁלוּ. מַאי מַשְׁמַע דְּהַאי ״זָדוּ״ לִישָּׁנָא דִקְדֵירָה הוּא — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיָּזֶד יַעֲקֹב נָזִיד״.
אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי סִימַאי: שְׁלֹשָׁה הָיוּ בְּאוֹתָהּ עֵצָה: בִּלְעָם, וְאִיּוֹב, וְיִתְרוֹ.

בִּלְעָם שֶׁיָּעַץ — נֶהֱרַג, אִיּוֹב שֶׁשָּׁתַק — נִידּוֹן בְּיִסּוּרִין. יִתְרוֹ שֶׁבָּרַח — זָכוּ מִבְּנֵי בָנָיו שֶׁיָּשְׁבוּ בְּלִשְׁכַּת הַגָּזִית, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּמִשְׁפְּחוֹת סוֹפְרִים יוֹשְׁבֵי יַעְבֵּץ תִּרְעָתִים שִׁמְעָתִים שׂוּכָתִים הֵמָּה הַקִּינִים הַבָּאִים מֵחַמַּת אֲבִי בֵית רֵכָב״, וּכְתִיב: ״וּבְנֵי קֵינִי חֹתֵן מֹשֶׁה וְגוֹ׳״.
״וְנִלְחַם בָּנוּ וְעָלָה מִן הָאָרֶץ״, ״וְעָלִינוּ״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא בַּר כָּהֲנָא: כְּאָדָם שֶׁמְּקַלֵּל אֶת עַצְמוֹ, וְתוֹלֶה קִלְלָתוֹ בַּחֲבֵירוֹ.

״וַיָּשִׂימוּ עָלָיו שָׂרֵי מִסִּים״, ״עֲלֵיהֶם״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! תָּנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן: מְלַמֵּד שֶׁהֵבִיאוּ מַלְבֵּן וְתָלוּ לוֹ לְפַרְעֹה בְּצַוָּארוֹ, וְכׇל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁאָמַר לָהֶם אִיסְטְנִיס אֲנִי, אָמְרוּ לוֹ: כְּלוּם אִיסְטְנִיס אַתָּה יוֹתֵר מִפַּרְעֹה?
״שָׂרֵי מִסִּים״, דָּבָר שֶׁמֵּשִׂים (לְבֵנִים).
״לְמַעַן עַנּוֹתוֹ בְּסִבְלוֹתָם״, [״עַנּוֹתָם״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ]! לְמַעַן עַנּוֹתוֹ לְפַרְעֹה בְּסִבְלוֹתָם דְּיִשְׂרָאֵל.

״וַיִּבֶן עָרֵי מִסְכְּנוֹת לְפַרְעֹה״, רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, חַד אָמַר: שֶׁמְּסַכְּנוֹת אֶת בַּעְלֵיהֶן. וְחַד אָמַר: שֶׁמְּמַסְכְּנוֹת אֶת בַּעְלֵיהֶן, דְּאָמַר מָר: כׇּל הָעוֹסֵק בְּבִנְיָן מִתְמַסְכֵּן.

״אֶת פִּיתוֹם וְאֶת רַעַמְסֵס״. רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, חַד אָמַר: פִּיתוֹם שְׁמָהּ, וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמָהּ רַעַמְסֵס — שֶׁרִאשׁוֹן רִאשׁוֹן מִתְרוֹסֵס. וְחַד אָמַר: רַעַמְסֵס שְׁמָהּ, וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמָהּ פִּיתוֹם — שֶׁרִאשׁוֹן רִאשׁוֹן פִּי תְהוֹם בּוֹלְעוֹ.

״וְכַאֲשֶׁר יְעַנּוּ אוֹתוֹ כֵּן יִרְבֶּה וְכֵן יִפְרוֹץ״. ״כֵּן רַבּוּ וְכֵן פָּרְצוּ״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! אָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: רוּחַ הַקֹּדֶשׁ מְבַשַּׂרְתָּן: ״כֵּן יִרְבֶּה וְכֵן יִפְרוֹץ״. ״וַיָּקֻצוּ מִפְּנֵי בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״, מְלַמֵּד שֶׁהָיוּ דּוֹמִין בְּעֵינֵיהֶם כְּקוֹצִים.
״וַיַּעֲבִדוּ מִצְרַיִם אֶת בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל
בְּפָרֶךְ״, רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אָמַר: בְּפֶה רַךְ. רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר: בִּפְרִיכָה.
״וַיְמָרְרוּ אֶת חַיֵּיהֶם בַּעֲבֹדָה קָשָׁה בְּחֹמֶר וּבִלְבֵנִים וְגוֹ׳״, אָמַר רָבָא: בַּתְּחִילָּה ״בְּחוֹמֶר וּבִלְבֵנִים״, וּלְבַסּוֹף ״וּבְכׇל עֲבוֹדָה בַּשָּׂדֶה״.

״אֵת כׇּל עֲבֹדָתָם אֲשֶׁר עָבְדוּ בָהֶם בְּפָרֶךְ״, אָמַר רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן: שֶׁהָיוּ מַחְלִיפִין מְלֶאכֶת אֲנָשִׁים לְנָשִׁים וּמְלֶאכֶת נָשִׁים לַאֲנָשִׁים. וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר נָמֵי הָתָם בְּפֶה רַךְ, הָכָא וַדַּאי בִּפְרִיכָה.

דָּרֵשׁ רַב עַוִּירָא: בִּשְׂכַר נָשִׁים צִדְקָנִיּוֹת שֶׁהָיוּ בְּאוֹתוֹ הַדּוֹר נִגְאֲלוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל מִמִּצְרַיִם. בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁהוֹלְכוֹת לִשְׁאוֹב מַיִם, הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא מְזַמֵּן לָהֶם דָּגִים קְטַנִּים בְּכַדֵּיהֶן, וְשׁוֹאֲבוֹת מֶחֱצָה מַיִם וּמֶחֱצָה דָּגִים, וּבָאוֹת וְשׁוֹפְתוֹת שְׁתֵּי קְדֵירוֹת, אַחַת שֶׁל חַמִּין וְאַחַת שֶׁל דָּגִים.

וּמוֹלִיכוֹת אֵצֶל בַּעְלֵיהֶן לַשָּׂדֶה, וּמַרְחִיצוֹת אוֹתָן, וְסָכוֹת אוֹתָן, וּמַאֲכִילוֹת אוֹתָן, וּמַשְׁקוֹת אוֹתָן, וְנִזְקָקוֹת לָהֶן בֵּין שְׁפַתַּיִם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אִם תִּשְׁכְּבוּן בֵּין שְׁפַתָּיִם וְגוֹ׳״, בִּשְׂכַר ״תִּשְׁכְּבוּן בֵּין שְׁפַתָּיִם״ זָכוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל לְבִיזַּת מִצְרַיִם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כַּנְפֵי יוֹנָה נֶחְפָּה בַכֶּסֶף וְאֶבְרוֹתֶיהָ בִּירַקְרַק חָרוּץ״.
וְכֵיוָן שֶׁמִּתְעַבְּרוֹת בָּאוֹת לְבָתֵּיהֶם, וְכֵיוָן שֶׁמַּגִּיעַ זְמַן מוֹלְדֵיהֶן הוֹלְכוֹת וְיוֹלְדוֹת בַּשָּׂדֶה תַּחַת הַתַּפּוּחַ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״תַּחַת הַתַּפּוּחַ עוֹרַרְתִּיךָ וְגוֹ׳״.

וְהַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא שׁוֹלֵחַ מִשְּׁמֵי מָרוֹם מִי שֶׁמְּנַקֵּיר וּמְשַׁפֵּיר אוֹתָן, כְּחַיָּה זוֹ שֶׁמְּשַׁפֶּרֶת אֶת הַוָּלָד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּמוֹלְדוֹתַיִךְ בְּיוֹם הוּלֶּדֶת אוֹתָךְ לֹא כׇרַּת שׇׁרֵּךְ וּבְמַיִם לֹא רֻחַצְתְּ לְמִשְׁעִי וְגוֹ׳״. וּמְלַקֵּט לָהֶן שְׁנֵי עִגּוּלִין, אֶחָד שֶׁל שֶׁמֶן וְאֶחָד שֶׁל דְּבַשׁ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֵּנִקֵהוּ דְבַשׁ מִסֶּלַע וְשֶׁמֶן וְגוֹ׳״.

וְכֵיוָן שֶׁמַּכִּירִין בָּהֶן מִצְרִים בָּאִין לְהוֹרְגָן, וְנַעֲשָׂה לָהֶם נֵס וְנִבְלָעִין בַּקַּרְקַע, וּמְבִיאִין שְׁוָורִים וְחוֹרְשִׁין עַל גַּבָּן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״עַל גַּבִּי חָרְשׁוּ חֹרְשִׁים וְגוֹ׳״. לְאַחַר שֶׁהוֹלְכִין הָיוּ מְבַצְבְּצִין וְיוֹצְאִין כְּעֵשֶׂב הַשָּׂדֶה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״רְבָבָה כְּצֶמַח הַשָּׂדֶה נְתַתִּיךְ״.

וְכֵיוָן שֶׁמִּתְגַּדְּלִין בָּאִין עֲדָרִים עֲדָרִים לְבָתֵּיהֶן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַתִּרְבִּי וַתִּגְדְּלִי וַתָּבֹאִי בַּעֲדִי עֲדָיִים״, אַל תִּקְרֵי ״בַּעֲדִי עֲדָיִים״, אֶלָּא ״בְּעֶדְרֵי עֲדָרִים״.
וּכְשֶׁנִּגְלָה הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא עַל הַיָּם, הֵם הִכִּירוּהוּ תְּחִלָּה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״זֶה אֵלִי וְאַנְוֵהוּ״.

״וַיֹּאמֶר מֶלֶךְ מִצְרַיִם לַמְיַלְּדוֹת הָעִבְרִיּוֹת וְגוֹ׳״. רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, חַד אָמַר: אִשָּׁה וּבִתָּהּ, וְחַד אָמַר: כַּלָּה וַחֲמוֹתָהּ. מַאן דְּאָמַר אִשָּׁה וּבִתָּהּ — יוֹכֶבֶד וּמִרְיָם, וּמַאן דְּאָמַר כַּלָּה וַחֲמוֹתָהּ — יוֹכֶבֶד וֶאֱלִישֶׁבַע.

תַּנְיָא כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר אִשָּׁה וּבִתָּהּ, דְּתַנְיָא: שִׁפְרָה זוֹ יוֹכֶבֶד, וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמָהּ שִׁפְרָה — שֶׁמְּשַׁפֶּרֶת אֶת הַוָּלָד. דָּבָר אַחֵר: ״שִׁפְרָה״ — שֶׁפָּרוּ וְרָבוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּיָמֶיהָ.

״פּוּעָה״ — זוֹ מִרְיָם. וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמָהּ ״פּוּעָה״ שֶׁהָיְתָה פּוֹעָה וּמוֹצִיאָה אֶת הַוָּלָד. דָּבָר אַחֵר: ״פּוּעָה״ — שֶׁהָיְתָה פּוֹעָה בְּרוּחַ הַקּוֹדֶשׁ וְאוֹמֶרֶת: עֲתִידָה אִמִּי שֶׁתֵּלֵד בֵּן שֶׁמּוֹשִׁיעַ אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל.

״וַיֹּאמֶר בְּיַלֶּדְכֶן אֶת הָעִבְרִיּוֹת וְגוֹ׳״. מַאי ״אׇבְנָיִם״ — אָמַר רַבִּי חָנָן: סִימָן גָּדוֹל מָסַר לָהֶן. אָמַר לָהֶן: בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁכּוֹרַעַת לֵילֵד יַרְכוֹתֶיהָ מִצְטַנְּנוֹת כַּאֲבָנִים.

וְאִית דְּאָמַר, כְּדִכְתִיב: ״וָאֵרֵד בֵּית הַיּוֹצֵר וְהִנֵּה הוּא עוֹשֶׂה מְלָאכָה עַל הָאׇבְנָיִם״, מָה יוֹצֵר זֶה — יָרֵךְ מִכָּאן וְיָרֵךְ מִכָּאן וְסַדָּן בָּאֶמְצַע, אַף אִשָּׁה — יָרֵךְ מִכָּאן וְיָרֵךְ מִכָּאן וְהַוָּלָד בָּאֶמְצַע.
״אִם בֵּן הוּא וַהֲמִתֶּן אוֹתוֹ״. אָמַר רַבִּי חֲנִינָא, סִימָן גָּדוֹל מָסַר לָהֶן: בֵּן פָּנָיו לְמַטָּה, בַּת פָּנֶיהָ לְמַעְלָה.

״וַתִּירֶאןָ הַמְיַלְּדוֹת אֶת הָאֱלֹהִים וְלֹא עָשׂוּ כַּאֲשֶׁר דִּבֶּר אֲלֵיהֶן וְגוֹ׳״. ״לָהֶן״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: מְלַמֵּד שֶׁתְּבָעָן לִדְבַר עֲבֵירָה וְלֹא נִתְבְּעוּ.
״וַתְּחַיֶּיןָ אֶת הַיְּלָדִים״. תָּנָא: לֹא דַּיָּין שֶׁלֹּא הֵמִיתוּ אוֹתָן, אֶלָּא שֶׁהָיוּ מַסְפִּיקוֹת לָהֶם מַיִם וּמָזוֹן.
״וַתֹּאמַרְןָ הַמְיַלְּדוֹת אֶל פַּרְעֹה כִּי לֹא כַנָּשִׁים וְגוֹ׳״. מַאי ״חָיוֹת״? אִילֵימָא חַיּוֹת מַמָּשׁ, אַטּוּ חַיָּה מִי לָא צְרִיכָה חַיָּה אַחֲרִיתִי לְאוֹלוֹדַהּ?

אֶלָּא אָמְרוּ לוֹ, אוּמָּה זוֹ כְּחַיָּה נִמְשְׁלָה: יְהוּדָה — ״גּוּר אַרְיֵה״, דָּן — ״יְהִי דָן נָחָשׁ״, ״נַפְתָּלִי אַיָּלָה שְׁלֻחָה״, ״יִשָּׂשכָר חֲמוֹר גָּרֶם״, יוֹסֵף — ״בְּכוֹר שׁוֹר״, ״בִּנְיָמִין זְאֵב יִטְרָף״.
דִּכְתִיב בֵּיהּ — כְּתִיב בֵּיהּ. וּדְלָא כְּתִיב בֵּיהּ — כְּתִיב בֵּיהּ: ״מַה אִמְּךָ לְבִיָּא בֵּין אֲרָיוֹת רָבָצָה וְגוֹ׳״.

״וַיְהִי כִּי יָרְאוּ הַמְיַלְּדוֹת אֶת הָאֱלֹהִים וַיַּעַשׂ לָהֶם בָּתִּים״. רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, חַד אָמַר: בָּתֵּי כְהוּנָּה וּלְוִיָּה, וְחַד אָמַר: בָּתֵּי מַלְכוּת. מַאן דְּאָמַר בָּתֵּי כְהוּנָּה וּלְוִיָּה — אַהֲרֹן וּמֹשֶׁה. וּמַאן דְּאָמַר בָּתֵּי מַלְכוּת — דָּוִד נָמֵי מִמִּרְיָם קָאָתֵי, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַתָּמׇת עֲזוּבָה אֵשֶׁת כָּלֵב וַיִּקַּח לוֹ כָלֵב אֶת אֶפְרָת וַתֵּלֶד לוֹ אֶת חוּר״. וּכְתִיב: ״וְדָוִד בֶּן אִישׁ אֶפְרָתִי וְגוֹ׳״.
״וְכָלֵב בֶּן חֶצְרוֹן הוֹלִיד אֶת עֲזוּבָה אִשָּׁה וְאֶת יְרִיעוֹת וְאֵלֶּה בָנֶיהָ יֵשֶׁר וְשׁוֹבָב וְאַרְדּוֹן״. בֶּן חֶצְרוֹן? בֶּן יְפֻנֶּה הוּא! בֵּן שֶׁפָּנָה מֵעֲצַת מְרַגְּלִים.
וְאַכַּתִּי: בֶּן קְנַז הוּא, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּלְכְּדָהּ עׇתְנִיאֵל בֶּן קְנַז אֲחִי כָלֵב״! אָמַר רָבָא: חוֹרְגוֹ דִּקְנַז הֲוָה.
human_translation: as it is written Behold, I will raise up evil against you out of your own house” Similarly, you can say “And he sent him from the valley [ emek ] of Hebron” Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa says: From the deep [ amukka ] counsel of that righteous individual who is interred in Hebron, as it is written: Know that your seed shall be a stranger

“For he said: I have no son And did not have sons? But isn’t it written: “And to Absalom there were born three sons, and one daughter” Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi says: that he did not have a son worthy for royalty. Rav Ḥisda said: It is learned Anyone who burns the produce of another does not leave a son to inherit him, and he, burned of Joab, as it is written: “Therefore he said to his servants: See, Joab’s field is near mine, and he has barley there; go and set it on fire. And Absalom’s servants set the field on fire”
And the same with regard to the good Miriam Are comparable? There, one hour, here, seven days. Abaye said: Say And with regard to good it is not so,

Rava said to him: But taught And the same with regard to the good Rather, Rava said: This is what is teaching: And the same with regard to the good with the same measure, but the measure of good is always greater than the measure of punishment.

“And his sister stood afar off, Rabbi Yitzḥak says: This entire verse is stated in reference to the Divine Presence, “And stood”; as it is written: “And the Lord came, and stood” “His sister”; as it is written: “Say to wisdom: You are my sister” “Afar off”; as it is written: “From afar the Lord appeared to me” “To know”; as it is written: “For the Lord is a God of knowledge” “What”; as it is written: “What does the Lord God require of you” “Would be done”; as it is written: “For the Lord God will do nothing” “To him”; as it is written: “And the Lord said to him: Peace

“And there arose a new king Rav and Shmuel One says actually a new and one says that his decrees were transformed The one who says actually a new because it is written “new.” And the one who says that his decrees were transformed because it is not written: “And died and reigned.” “Who knew not Joseph” that he was like someone who did not know him at all.

“And he said to his people: Behold, the people of the children of Israel taught He, initiated the proposal. Therefore, he was stricken first. He initiated the proposal, as it is written: “And he said to his people.” Therefore, he was stricken first, as it is written: both upon you, and upon your people, and upon all your servants”
“Come, let us deal wisely with him [ lo ], He should have With them [ lahem ], Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says Come, let us deal wisely with regard to the savior of Israel,

With what shall we judge them? we shall judge them with fire, it is written: “For behold, the Lord will come in fire” it is written “For by fire will the Lord contend” with the sword, it is written “And by His sword with all flesh”

Rather, let us come and judge them with water, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, already took an oath that He will not bring a flood upon the world, as it is stated: “For this is as the waters of Noah unto Me; And did not know that He will not bring a flood upon all the world, but He bring upon one nation.

Alternatively, He does not bring but they come and fall into and so it says: and the Egyptians fled toward it; And this is what Rabbi Elazar says: What is the which is written: for in that which they conspired [ zadu ] against them” In the pot in which they cooked, they were cooked, From where may be inferred that this “ zadu ” is a term a pot? As it is written: “And Jacob simmered a pot [ vayyazed Ya’akov nazid ]”
Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says Rabbi Simai says: Three were in that counsel Balaam, and Job, and Yitro.

Balaam, who advised was killed Job, who was silent was punished by suffering, Yitro, who ran away merited that of his children’s children sat in the Chamber of Hewn Stone, as it is stated: “And the families of scribes who dwelt at Jabez, Tirathites, Shimeathites, and Sucathites, these were the Kenites who descended from Hammath, the father of the house of Rechab” And it is written: “The children of the Kenite, Moses’ father-in-law”
and fight against us, and get him up out of the land” He should have And get us up, Rabbi Abba bar Kahana says: is like a person who curses himself applies his curse to another.

“Therefore they did set over him taskmasters It should have Over them, The school of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, taught: teaches they brought a brick mold and they hung it on the neck of Pharaoh And each and every Jew who said to I am a delicate person [ istenis ] they said to him: Are you at all more of a delicate person than Pharaoh,
“Taskmasters [ sarei missim ]” A matter that compels [ shemesim ] bricks,
“In order to afflict him with their burdens” It should have “In order to afflict them,” in order to afflict Pharaoh, with the burdens of the Jewish people.

“And they built for Pharaoh storage cities [ miskenot ], Rav and Shmuel One says that endanger [ mesakenot ] their owners, And one says that impoverishes [ memaskenot ] their owners, as the Master said: All who engage in construction become poor.

“Pithom and Raamses” Rav and Shmuel One says Pithom its name, and why was it called Raamses? that they collapsed [ mitroses ] one by one And one says Raamses its name, and why was it called Pithom? the opening of the abyss [ pi tehom ] swallowed one by one, and it sunk into the ground.

“But the more they afflicted him, the more he would multiply and the more he would spread about” It should have The more they multiplied and the more they spread about, Reish Lakish says: Divine inspiration proclaimed to the more he will multiply and the more he will spread about. “And they became disgusted [ vayyakutzu ] due to the children of Israel.” teaches that appeared in their eyes like thorns [ kotzim ].
“And the Egyptians made the children of Israel work
with rigor [ befarekh ]” Rabbi Elazar says: With a soft mouth [ bifeh rakh ], Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says: With crushing [ bifrikha ],
“And they made their lives bitter through hard service, with mortar and brick, Rava says: initially with mortar and bricks, and ultimately “and with every laborious service in the field.”

“In all their service, wherein they made them serve with rigor” Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says Rabbi Yonatan says: would exchange men’s work to women and women’s work to men, And even according to the one who says there, with a soft mouth, here, certainly with crushing

Rav Avira taught: In the merit of righteous women that were in that generation, the Jewish people were redeemed from Egypt. At the time would go to draw water, the Holy One, Blessed be He, would materialize for them small fish into their pitchers, and they would draw half water and half fish. And they would come and place two pots on the fire, one of hot and one of fish

And they would take to their husbands, to the field, and would bathe and anoint them and feed them and give them to drink and bond with them between the sheepfolds, as it is stated: “When you lie among the sheepfolds, as a reward lie among the sheepfolds,” the Jewish people merited to the plunder of Egypt, as it is stated “The wings of the dove are covered with silver, and her pinions with the shimmer of gold”

And when become pregnant, they would come to their homes, and when the time for them to give birth they would go and give birth in the field under the apple tree, as it is stated: “Under the apple tree I awakened you;

And the Holy One, Blessed be He, would send from the heavens above who would clean and prepare just as a midwife prepares the newborn, as it is stated: “And as for your birth, on the day you were born, your navel was not cut nor were you washed with water for cleansing; And would gather for them two round One of oil and one of honey, as it is stated: “And He would suckle them with honey from a crag and oil

And once the Egyptians would notice them, they would come to kill them. But a miracle would occur for them and they would be absorbed by the earth. And would bring oxen and would plow upon them, as it is stated: “The plowers plowed upon my back; After would leave, would emerge and exit like grass of the field, as it is stated: “I caused you to increase even as the growth of the field”

And once would grow, they would come like many flocks to their homes, as it is stated “And you did increase and grow up and you came with excellent beauty [ ba’adi adayim ]” Do not read “ Ba’adi adayim ,” Rather, Be’edrei adarim ,
And when the Holy One, Blessed be He, revealed Himself at the Sea, recognized Him first, as it is stated: “This is my God, and I will glorify Him”

“And the king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives, Rav and Shmuel One says a woman and her daughter, and one says a daughter-in-law and her mother-in-law. one who says a woman and her daughter, Jochebed, and Miriam. And one who says a daughter-in-law and her mother-in-law, Jochebed and Elisheba,

is taught according to the one who says a woman and her daughter, because it taught Shiphrah, this Jochebed. And why was she called Shiphrah? Because she would prepare [ mishapperet ] the newborn. Alternatively, Shiphrah because the Jewish people increased and multiplied [ shepparu verabbu ] in her days,

Puah, this Miriam. And why was she called Puah? Because she would make a comforting sound [ po’a ] as she would remove the child Alternatively, Puah as she would speak [ po’a ] through divine inspiration and say: In the future, my mother will give birth to a son who will save the Jewish people.

“And he said: When you deliver the Hebrew women, What “stones”? Rabbi Ḥanan says: transmitted a great sign to them. He said to them: At the time crouches to give birth, her thighs become as cold as stones,

And there are those who say As it is written: “So I went down to the potter’s shop, and behold, he was at his work on the wheels [ ovnayim ]” Just as this potter thigh here and thigh there and the block is in the middle, so too, a woman thigh here and thigh there and the newborn is in the middle.
“If it be a son, then you shall kill him; Rabbi Ḥanina says: transmitted to them a great sign A boy his face downward; a girl her face upward.

“But the midwives feared God, and did not as the king of Egypt spoke about them [ aleihen ], It should have to them [ lahen ].” Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: teaches that proposed to them to a sinful act, but they did not accept
“But they kept the male children alive” teaches: not only that they did not kill but that they would provide for them water and food,
“And the midwives said to Pharaoh: Because are not as the women, What “ ḥayot ”? If we say actual midwives is that to say a midwife does not need another midwife to help her give birth?

Rather, said to This nation is compared to an animal [ ḥayya ], Judah a lion’s whelp” Dan “Dan shall be a serpent Naphtali “A hind let loose” Issachar “A large-boned donkey” Joseph first bullock” Benjamin “A ravenous wolf”
where is written with regard to him, is written with regard to him. And where no written with regard to him is written about “How your mother was a lioness; among lions she crouched,

“And it came to pass, because the midwives feared God, that He made them houses” Rav and Shmuel One says the houses of priesthood and Levites and one says houses of royalty The one who says houses of priesthood and Levites Aaron and Moses, And the one who says houses of royalty David, also comes from Miriam, as it is written: “And Azubah,” the wife of Caleb, “died, and Caleb took to him Ephrath, who bore him Hur” And it is written: “David was the son of that Ephrathite

“And Caleb, the son of Hezron, begot children of Azubah his wife, and of Jerioth, and these were her sons: Jesher, and Shobab, and Ardon” son of Hezron? Wasn’t he son of Jephunneh, a son who turned away [ sheppana ] from the counsel of the spies.
But still was son of Kenaz, as it is written: “And Othniel, the son of Kenaz, Caleb’s brother, took it” Rava said: was the stepson of Kenaz,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: As it is written: "Behold, I am bringing evil upon you from your own house." By way of analogy, you may say: "And he sent him away from the valley of Hebron." Rabbi Chanina bar Papa said: With the deep counsel of that righteous one who is buried in Hebron, as it is written: "You shall surely know that your descendants will be strangers."

"When he said, 'I have no son,' did he not have sons? But it is written: 'And to Absalom were born three sons and one daughter'! Rav Yitzchak bar Avdimi said: He did not have a son fitting for the kingdom. Rav Chisda said, it is a tradition: Anyone who burns his friend's produce does not leave a son to inherit from him. And he called it a 'portion' to Joab, as it is written: 'And he said to his servants, 'See, Joab's portion is by my hand, and there is barley there. Go and set it on fire.' So the servants of Absalom set the portion on fire."
And so regarding the matter of the well of Miriam, etc. Who is comparable? There — one hour, here — seven days! Abaye said, I say: And regarding the matter of the well, it is not the same.

He said to him, Rava: This "and similarly for the matter of good" is what it teaches! Rather, Rava said, this is what it teaches: "And similarly for the matter of good," in that measure, and forever a measure of good is greater than a measure of punishment.

"And his sister stood at a distance," Rabbi Yitzchak said: This entire verse is stated in reference to the Divine Presence. "And she stood" - as it is written: "And Hashem came and stood." "His sister" - as it is written: "Say to wisdom, 'You are my sister.'" "From a distance" - as it is written: "From a distance, Hashem appeared to me." "To know" - as it is written: "For the knowledge of Hashem." "What" - as it is written: "What does Hashem your God ask of you." "Will be done" - as it is written: "For Hashem God will not do a thing." "To him" - as it is written: "And Hashem said to him, 'Peace.'"

"And a new king arose, etc." Rav and Shmuel, one said: literally new, and one said: that his decrees were renewed. The one who said literally new - as it is written "new," and the one who said that his decrees were renewed, for it is not written "and he died and he reigned." "Who did not know Joseph," it is as if he did not know him at all.

Talmudic text: "And he said to his people, 'Behold, the people of the children of Israel.'" It was taught: He began with counsel first, therefore he was struck first. He began with counsel first - as it is written: "And he said to his people," therefore he was struck first - as it is written: "And on you and on your people and on all your servants."
"Let us be wise for him." "For them" - who needs it for him! Rabbi Ḥama son of Rabbi Ḥanina said: Come, let us be wise for the Savior of Israel —

In what are they judged? They are judged by fire - as it is written: "For behold, the Lord will come in fire," and it is written: "For by fire will the Lord execute judgment, etc." By sword - as it is written: "And with His sword He will judge all flesh."

Rather, come and let us reason with them in water, for the Holy One, blessed be He, has already sworn that He will never bring a flood upon the world, as it is stated: "For this is as the waters of Noah to Me." And they do not know that He does not bring it upon the entire world, but upon one nation He brings it.

Talmudic text: "Iy namei: hu einu mevi, aval hen ba'in v'noflin b'tokho. V'chen hu omer: 'uMitzrayim nasim likrato.' V'hainu de'amar Rabbi Elazar: Ma'i dikhtiv 'ki badavar asher zadu aleihem' — b'kidira shebishlu, bah nitbashlu. Ma'i mashma dehai 'zadu' lishna dikidira hu — dikhtiv: 'vayazed Yaakov nazid.'" English translation: "If it is not brought, but they come and fall into it. And similarly, it says: 'Egypt hastens to meet him.' And this is what Rabbi Elazar said: What is the meaning of 'for they were arrogant in what they cooked' — in the pot in which they cooked, they were cooked. What is implied by 'arrogant' in the context of a pot? — as it is written: 'And Jacob cooked a stew.'"
Said Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said Rabbi Simai: Three were in that council: Bilaam, Job, and Jethro.

Bilam sheya'atz - neharg, Iyov she'shatak - nidon be'yissurin. Yitro she'barach - zachoo mibnei banav she'yashvu be'lishkat hagazit, shene'emar: "U'mishpechot sofrim yoshvei Ya'betz Tiratim shima'atim sukhatim hemah hakinnim haba'im me'chatat avi beit rechav," u'chtiv: "U'venei Keini chotein Moshe ve'go."
"And he will fight with us and go up from the land," "and we will go up" - who is it referring to? Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said: Like a person who curses himself, and hangs his curse on his fellow.

"And they placed over him officers of burdens," "over them" - who is it referring to? It was taught in the school of Rabbi Elazar son of Rabbi Shimon: This teaches that they brought a collar and hung it on Pharaoh's neck, and each and every one of the Israelites who said to them, "I am an officer of burdens," they said to him: Are you more of an officer of burdens than Pharaoh?
"Princes of spices," a matter that they use (for) (whitening) (teeth).
"To afflict him in their burdens," It should have said "their affliction"! To afflict him, to Pharaoh, in their burdens of the children of Israel.

"And he built supply cities for Pharaoh," Rav and Shmuel, one said: that they supplied their husbands. And one said: that they supplied their husbands, as the Master said: anyone who engages in building becomes impoverished.

"The depths and Ramses." Rav and Shmuel, one said: Its name is "the depths," and why is it called by the name "Ramses" - because it first begins to sink. And one said: Its name is "Ramses," and why is it called by the name "the depths" - because it first begins to swallow the mouth of the deep.

"And as he afflicted him, so he multiplied and so he broke forth." "So they increased and so they spread out." What does he want with this? Reish Lakish said: The Holy Spirit proclaims: "So he multiplied and so he broke forth." "And they were loathsome before the children of Israel," teaching that they appeared in their eyes like thorns.
"And they enslaved Egypt the sons of Israel."
In the marketplace, Rabbi Elazar said: with a soft mouth. Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said: with a ripe fig.
"And they embittered their lives with hard labor, with clay and bricks, etc." Rava said: Initially "with clay and bricks," and ultimately "with all the work in the field."

"The entirety of their labor that they worked with them in the parochet," Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said in the name of Rabbi Yonatan: They would interchange the work of men for women and the work of women for men. And according to the one who said there, 'with a soft mouth,' here certainly with a paricha."

Rav Avira expounded: In the merit of the righteous women of that generation, the Israelites were redeemed from Egypt. When they went to draw water, the Holy One, blessed be He, would prepare small fish for them in their pitchers. They would draw half water and half fish, and they would come and pour into two pots, one for hot water and one for fish.

And they lead him to their husbands to the field, and they wash them, and they anoint them, and they feed them, and they give them drink, and they adorn themselves for them between the lips, as it is stated: "If you lie between the lips, etc." In reward for "you lie between the lips," the Israelites merited the spoils of Egypt, as it is stated: "The wings of a dove are covered with silver, and her pinions with yellow gold."

And when they become pregnant, they come back to their homes, and when the time of their giving birth arrives, they go and give birth in the field under the apple tree, as it is said: "Under the apple tree I awakened you..."

The Holy One, blessed be He, sends from the heights of heaven one who pierces and beautifies them, like this animal that beautifies the newborn, as it is said: "And as for your birth, on the day you were born your navel cord was not cut, nor were you washed with water for cleansing, nor rubbed with salt, etc." And he gathers for her two cakes, one of oil and one of honey, as it is said: "He nourished him with honey from the rock, and oil, etc."

Talmudic text: And when the Egyptians recognize them, they come to kill them, and a miracle occurs for them, and they are swallowed up by the ground, and they bring oxen and plow over them, as it is said: "They plowed upon my back plowers." After they go, they become crushed and come out like the grass of the field, as it is said: "I made you numerous like the plants of the field."

And when they grow, they come in flocks, flocks to their homes, as it is stated: "And you grew up and became tall and reached full womanhood; your breasts were formed" (Ezekiel 16:7). Do not read "your breasts were formed," but rather "in flocks of flocks."
And when the Holy One, blessed be He, was revealed upon the sea, they recognized Him first, as it is said: "This is my God, and I will glorify Him."

"And the king of Egypt said to the Hebrew midwives, etc." Rav and Shmuel, one said: "A woman and her daughter," and one said: "A bride and her mother-in-law." The one who said "a woman and her daughter" - Yocheved and Miriam, and the one who said "a bride and her mother-in-law" - Yocheved and Elisheva.

It was taught in a baraita according to the opinion that says, "A woman and her daughter," as it was taught: "Shifra" - this is Yocheved. And why was she called Shifra? Because she beautified the child. Another explanation: "Shifra" - that they multiplied and increased the Israelites in her days.

"Puah" - this is Miriam. And why was she called "Puah"? Because she would cry out and deliver the infant. Another explanation: "Puah" - because she would cry out with the Holy Spirit and say: "My mother is destined to give birth to a son who will save Israel."

"And he said, 'When you help the Hebrew women in childbirth, and so on.'" What is "Avnayim"? - Rabbi Hanan said: He gave them a great sign. He said to them: At the moment when she crouches to give birth, her hips become cold like stones.

And there are those who say, as it is written: "And I went down to the potter's house, and behold, he was working at the wheels." What is this potter? One leg here and one leg there, and the private parts in the middle; so too with a woman - one leg here and one leg there, and the child is in the middle.
"If he is a son, then give him." Rabbi Chanina said, a great sign was given to them: a son should have his face downwards, a daughter should have her face upwards.

"And the midwives feared God and did not do as the king of Egypt spoke to them, etc." "To them" - it should have said "to them"! Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina said: This teaches that they demanded to speak of sin, but they were not answered.
"And she gave life to the children." It was taught: Not that they did not kill them, but that they provided them with sufficient water and food.

"And the midwives said to Pharaoh, 'Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women.'" What is meant by "חָיוֹת"? If you say actual animals, then does an animal need another animal to give birth to it?

Instead, they said to him, what is this animal compared to: Judah - "a lion's cub," Dan - "Dan shall be a serpent," "Naphtali is a hind let loose," "Issachar is a strong-boned donkey," Joseph - "the firstborn bull," "Benjamin is a wolf that tears."
It is written in it - it is written in it. And if it is not written in it - it is written in it: "What is your mother like? A lioness among lions..."

"And it came to pass, when the midwives feared God, that He made them houses." Rav and Shmuel, one said: houses of priesthood and Levites, and one said: houses of royalty. Whoever said houses of priesthood and Levites—Aaron and Moses. And whoever said houses of royalty—David also from Miriam descends, as it is written: "And she was left by her husband Caleb, and Caleb took for himself Ephrath, and she bore him Hur." And it is written: "And David, the son of an Ephrathite man, etc."

"And Caleb son of Hezron fathered Azubah, wife, and Jerioth, and these her sons: Jesher and Shobab and Ardon." Son of Hezron? He is the son of Jephunneh! Son of Shephatiah from the counsel of the spies.
And once: Ben K'naz he, as it is written: "And Othniel the son of Kenaz, Caleb's brother, took it." Rava said: He was Kenaz's weaver.

sentences.text: דִּכְתִיב: ״הִנְנִי מֵקִים עָלֶיךָ רָעָה מִבֵּיתֶךָ״. כַּיּוֹצֵא בַּדָּבָר אַתָּה אוֹמֵר: ״וַיִּשְׁלָחֵהוּ מֵעֵמֶק חֶבְרוֹן״, אָמַר רַבִּי חֲנִינָא בַּר פָּפָּא: בְּעֵצָה עֲמוּקָּה שֶׁל אוֹתוֹ צַדִּיק שֶׁקָּבוּר בְּחֶבְרוֹן, דִּכְתִיב: ״יָדֹעַ תֵּדַע כִּי גֵר יִהְיֶה זַרְעֲךָ״.
sentences.human_translation: as it is written Behold, I will raise up evil against you out of your own house” Similarly, you can say “And he sent him from the valley [ emek ] of Hebron” Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa says: From the deep [ amukka ] counsel of that righteous individual who is interred in Hebron, as it is written: Know that your seed shall be a stranger
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: As it is written: "Behold, I am bringing evil upon you from your own house." By way of analogy, you may say: "And he sent him away from the valley of Hebron." Rabbi Chanina bar Papa said: With the deep counsel of that righteous one who is buried in Hebron, as it is written: "You shall surely know that your descendants will be strangers."

sentences.text: ״כִּי אָמַר אֵין לִי בֵן״. וְלָא הֲווֹ לֵיהּ בְּנֵי? וְהָכְתִיב: ״וַיִּוָּלְדוּ לְאַבְשָׁלוֹם שְׁלֹשָׁה בָּנִים וּבַת אַחַת״! אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בַּר אַבְדִּימִי: שֶׁלֹּא הָיָה לוֹ בֵּן הָגוּן לַמַּלְכוּת. רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר, גְּמִירִי: כׇּל הַשּׂוֹרֵף תְּבוּאָתוֹ שֶׁל חֲבֵירוֹ, אֵינוֹ מַנִּיחַ בֵּן לְיוֹרְשׁוֹ. וְאִיהוּ קַלְיַיהּ לִדְיוֹאָב, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֹּאמֶר אֶל עֲבָדָיו רְאוּ חֶלְקַת יוֹאָב אֶל יָדִי וְלוֹ שָׁם שְׂעֹרִים לְכוּ וְהַצִּיתוּהָ בָאֵשׁ וַיַּצִּיתוּ עַבְדֵי אַבְשָׁלוֹם אֶת הַחֶלְקָה בָּאֵשׁ״.
sentences.human_translation: “For he said: I have no son And did not have sons? But isn’t it written: “And to Absalom there were born three sons, and one daughter” Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi says: that he did not have a son worthy for royalty. Rav Ḥisda said: It is learned Anyone who burns the produce of another does not leave a son to inherit him, and he, burned of Joab, as it is written: “Therefore he said to his servants: See, Joab’s field is near mine, and he has barley there; go and set it on fire. And Absalom’s servants set the field on fire”
sentences.llm_translation: "When he said, 'I have no son,' did he not have sons? But it is written: 'And to Absalom were born three sons and one daughter'! Rav Yitzchak bar Avdimi said: He did not have a son fitting for the kingdom. Rav Chisda said, it is a tradition: Anyone who burns his friend's produce does not leave a son to inherit from him. And he called it a 'portion' to Joab, as it is written: 'And he said to his servants, 'See, Joab's portion is by my hand, and there is barley there. Go and set it on fire.' So the servants of Absalom set the portion on fire."

sentences.text: וְכֵן לְעִנְיַן הַטּוֹבָה מִרְיָם וְכוּ׳. מִי דָּמֵי? הָתָם — חֲדָא שַׁעְתָּא, הָכָא — שִׁבְעָה יוֹמֵי! אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, אֵימָא: וּלְעִנְיַן הַטּוֹבָה אֵינוֹ כֵּן.
sentences.human_translation: And the same with regard to the good Miriam Are comparable? There, one hour, here, seven days. Abaye said: Say And with regard to good it is not so,
sentences.llm_translation: And so regarding the matter of the well of Miriam, etc. Who is comparable? There — one hour, here — seven days! Abaye said, I say: And regarding the matter of the well, it is not the same.

sentences.text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: הָא ״וְכֵן לְעִנְיַן הַטּוֹבָה״ קָתָנֵי! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא, הָכִי קָתָנֵי: וְכֵן לְעִנְיַן הַטּוֹבָה, דִּבְאוֹתָהּ מִדָּה, וּלְעוֹלָם מִדָּה טוֹבָה מְרוּבָּה מִמִּדַּת פּוּרְעָנוּת.
sentences.human_translation: Rava said to him: But taught And the same with regard to the good Rather, Rava said: This is what is teaching: And the same with regard to the good with the same measure, but the measure of good is always greater than the measure of punishment.
sentences.llm_translation: He said to him, Rava: This "and similarly for the matter of good" is what it teaches! Rather, Rava said, this is what it teaches: "And similarly for the matter of good," in that measure, and forever a measure of good is greater than a measure of punishment.

sentences.text: ״וַתֵּתַצַּב אֲחוֹתוֹ מֵרָחוֹק״, אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: פָּסוּק זֶה כּוּלּוֹ עַל שֵׁם שְׁכִינָה נֶאֱמַר: ״וַתֵּתַצַּב״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיָּבֹא ה׳ וַיִּתְיַצַּב וְגוֹ׳״. ״אֲחוֹתוֹ״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״אֱמֹר לַחׇכְמָה אֲחוֹתִי אָתְּ״. ״מֵרָחוֹק״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״מֵרָחוֹק ה׳ נִרְאָה לִי״. ״לָדַעַת״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי אֵל דֵּעוֹת ה׳״. ״מָה״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״מַה ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ שֹׁאֵל מֵעִמָּךְ״. ״יֵּעָשֶׂה״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי לֹא יַעֲשֶׂה ה׳ אֱלֹהִים דָּבָר״. ״לוֹ״ — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֹּאמֶר לוֹ ה׳ שָׁלוֹם״.
sentences.human_translation: “And his sister stood afar off, Rabbi Yitzḥak says: This entire verse is stated in reference to the Divine Presence, “And stood”; as it is written: “And the Lord came, and stood” “His sister”; as it is written: “Say to wisdom: You are my sister” “Afar off”; as it is written: “From afar the Lord appeared to me” “To know”; as it is written: “For the Lord is a God of knowledge” “What”; as it is written: “What does the Lord God require of you” “Would be done”; as it is written: “For the Lord God will do nothing” “To him”; as it is written: “And the Lord said to him: Peace
sentences.llm_translation: "And his sister stood at a distance," Rabbi Yitzchak said: This entire verse is stated in reference to the Divine Presence. "And she stood" - as it is written: "And Hashem came and stood." "His sister" - as it is written: "Say to wisdom, 'You are my sister.'" "From a distance" - as it is written: "From a distance, Hashem appeared to me." "To know" - as it is written: "For the knowledge of Hashem." "What" - as it is written: "What does Hashem your God ask of you." "Will be done" - as it is written: "For Hashem God will not do a thing." "To him" - as it is written: "And Hashem said to him, 'Peace.'"

sentences.text: ״וַיָּקׇם מֶלֶךְ חָדָשׁ וְגוֹ׳״. רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, חַד אָמַר: חָדָשׁ מַמָּשׁ, וְחַד אָמַר: שֶׁנִּתְחַדְּשׁוּ גְּזֵירוֹתָיו. מַאן דְּאָמַר חָדָשׁ מַמָּשׁ — דִּכְתִיב ״חָדָשׁ״, וּמַאן דְּאָמַר שֶׁנִּתְחַדְּשׁוּ גְּזֵירוֹתָיו, דְּלָא כְּתִיב ״וַיָּמׇת וַיִּמְלוֹךְ״. ״אֲשֶׁר לֹא יָדַע אֶת יוֹסֵף״, דַּהֲוָה דָּמֵי כְּמַאן דְּלָא יָדַע לֵיהּ כְּלָל.
sentences.human_translation: “And there arose a new king Rav and Shmuel One says actually a new and one says that his decrees were transformed The one who says actually a new because it is written “new.” And the one who says that his decrees were transformed because it is not written: “And died and reigned.” “Who knew not Joseph” that he was like someone who did not know him at all.
sentences.llm_translation: "And a new king arose, etc." Rav and Shmuel, one said: literally new, and one said: that his decrees were renewed. The one who said literally new - as it is written "new," and the one who said that his decrees were renewed, for it is not written "and he died and he reigned." "Who did not know Joseph," it is as if he did not know him at all.

sentences.text: ״וַיֹּאמֶר אֶל עַמּוֹ הִנֵּה עַם בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״. תָּנָא: הוּא הִתְחִיל בְּעֵצָה תְּחִילָּה לְפִיכָךְ לָקָה תְּחִילָּה. הוּא הִתְחִיל בְּעֵצָה תְּחִילָּה — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֹּאמֶר אֶל עַמּוֹ״, לְפִיכָךְ לָקָה תְּחִילָּה — כְּדִכְתִיב: ״וּבְכָה וּבְעַמְּךָ וּבְכׇל עֲבָדֶיךָ״.
sentences.human_translation: “And he said to his people: Behold, the people of the children of Israel taught He, initiated the proposal. Therefore, he was stricken first. He initiated the proposal, as it is written: “And he said to his people.” Therefore, he was stricken first, as it is written: both upon you, and upon your people, and upon all your servants”
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And he said to his people, 'Behold, the people of the children of Israel.'" It was taught: He began with counsel first, therefore he was struck first. He began with counsel first - as it is written: "And he said to his people," therefore he was struck first - as it is written: "And on you and on your people and on all your servants."

sentences.text: ״הָבָה נִתְחַכְּמָה לוֹ״. ״לָהֶם״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! אָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: בֹּאוּ וְנֶחְכַּם לְמוֹשִׁיעָן שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל —
sentences.human_translation: “Come, let us deal wisely with him [ lo ], He should have With them [ lahem ], Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says Come, let us deal wisely with regard to the savior of Israel,
sentences.llm_translation: "Let us be wise for him." "For them" - who needs it for him! Rabbi Ḥama son of Rabbi Ḥanina said: Come, let us be wise for the Savior of Israel —

sentences.text: בַּמֶּה נְדוּנֵם? נְדוּנֵם בָּאֵשׁ — כְּתִיב: ״כִּי הִנֵּה ה׳ בָּאֵשׁ יָבֹא״, וּכְתִיב: ״כִּי בָאֵשׁ ה׳ נִשְׁפָּט וְגוֹ׳״. בְּחֶרֶב — כְּתִיב: [״וּבְחַרְבּוֹ אֶת כׇּל בָּשָׂר״].
sentences.human_translation: With what shall we judge them? we shall judge them with fire, it is written: “For behold, the Lord will come in fire” it is written “For by fire will the Lord contend” with the sword, it is written “And by His sword with all flesh”
sentences.llm_translation: In what are they judged? They are judged by fire - as it is written: "For behold, the Lord will come in fire," and it is written: "For by fire will the Lord execute judgment, etc." By sword - as it is written: "And with His sword He will judge all flesh."

sentences.text: אֶלָּא בּוֹאוּ וּנְדוּנֵם בַּמַּיִם, שֶׁכְּבָר נִשְׁבַּע הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא שֶׁאֵינוֹ מֵבִיא מַבּוּל לָעוֹלָם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי מֵי נֹחַ זֹאת לִי וְגוֹ׳״. וְהֵן אֵינָן יוֹדְעִין שֶׁעַל כׇּל הָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ אֵינוֹ מֵבִיא, אֲבָל עַל אוּמָּה אַחַת הוּא מֵבִיא.
sentences.human_translation: Rather, let us come and judge them with water, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, already took an oath that He will not bring a flood upon the world, as it is stated: “For this is as the waters of Noah unto Me; And did not know that He will not bring a flood upon all the world, but He bring upon one nation.
sentences.llm_translation: Rather, come and let us reason with them in water, for the Holy One, blessed be He, has already sworn that He will never bring a flood upon the world, as it is stated: "For this is as the waters of Noah to Me." And they do not know that He does not bring it upon the entire world, but upon one nation He brings it.

sentences.text: אִי נָמֵי: הוּא אֵינוֹ מֵבִיא, אֲבָל הֵן בָּאִין וְנוֹפְלִין בְּתוֹכוֹ. וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וּמִצְרַיִם נָסִים לִקְרָאתוֹ״. וְהַיְינוּ דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״כִּי בַדָּבָר אֲשֶׁר זָדוּ עֲלֵיהֶם״ — בִּקְדֵירָה שֶׁבִּישְּׁלוּ, בָּהּ נִתְבַּשְּׁלוּ. מַאי מַשְׁמַע דְּהַאי ״זָדוּ״ לִישָּׁנָא דִקְדֵירָה הוּא — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיָּזֶד יַעֲקֹב נָזִיד״.
sentences.human_translation: Alternatively, He does not bring but they come and fall into and so it says: and the Egyptians fled toward it; And this is what Rabbi Elazar says: What is the which is written: for in that which they conspired [ zadu ] against them” In the pot in which they cooked, they were cooked, From where may be inferred that this “ zadu ” is a term a pot? As it is written: “And Jacob simmered a pot [ vayyazed Ya’akov nazid ]”
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Iy namei: hu einu mevi, aval hen ba'in v'noflin b'tokho. V'chen hu omer: 'uMitzrayim nasim likrato.' V'hainu de'amar Rabbi Elazar: Ma'i dikhtiv 'ki badavar asher zadu aleihem' — b'kidira shebishlu, bah nitbashlu. Ma'i mashma dehai 'zadu' lishna dikidira hu — dikhtiv: 'vayazed Yaakov nazid.'" English translation: "If it is not brought, but they come and fall into it. And similarly, it says: 'Egypt hastens to meet him.' And this is what Rabbi Elazar said: What is the meaning of 'for they were arrogant in what they cooked' — in the pot in which they cooked, they were cooked. What is implied by 'arrogant' in the context of a pot? — as it is written: 'And Jacob cooked a stew.'"

sentences.text: אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי סִימַאי: שְׁלֹשָׁה הָיוּ בְּאוֹתָהּ עֵצָה: בִּלְעָם, וְאִיּוֹב, וְיִתְרוֹ.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says Rabbi Simai says: Three were in that counsel Balaam, and Job, and Yitro.
sentences.llm_translation: Said Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said Rabbi Simai: Three were in that council: Bilaam, Job, and Jethro.

sentences.text: בִּלְעָם שֶׁיָּעַץ — נֶהֱרַג, אִיּוֹב שֶׁשָּׁתַק — נִידּוֹן בְּיִסּוּרִין. יִתְרוֹ שֶׁבָּרַח — זָכוּ מִבְּנֵי בָנָיו שֶׁיָּשְׁבוּ בְּלִשְׁכַּת הַגָּזִית, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּמִשְׁפְּחוֹת סוֹפְרִים יוֹשְׁבֵי יַעְבֵּץ תִּרְעָתִים שִׁמְעָתִים שׂוּכָתִים הֵמָּה הַקִּינִים הַבָּאִים מֵחַמַּת אֲבִי בֵית רֵכָב״, וּכְתִיב: ״וּבְנֵי קֵינִי חֹתֵן מֹשֶׁה וְגוֹ׳״.
sentences.human_translation: Balaam, who advised was killed Job, who was silent was punished by suffering, Yitro, who ran away merited that of his children’s children sat in the Chamber of Hewn Stone, as it is stated: “And the families of scribes who dwelt at Jabez, Tirathites, Shimeathites, and Sucathites, these were the Kenites who descended from Hammath, the father of the house of Rechab” And it is written: “The children of the Kenite, Moses’ father-in-law”
sentences.llm_translation: Bilam sheya'atz - neharg, Iyov she'shatak - nidon be'yissurin. Yitro she'barach - zachoo mibnei banav she'yashvu be'lishkat hagazit, shene'emar: "U'mishpechot sofrim yoshvei Ya'betz Tiratim shima'atim sukhatim hemah hakinnim haba'im me'chatat avi beit rechav," u'chtiv: "U'venei Keini chotein Moshe ve'go."

sentences.text: ״וְנִלְחַם בָּנוּ וְעָלָה מִן הָאָרֶץ״, ״וְעָלִינוּ״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא בַּר כָּהֲנָא: כְּאָדָם שֶׁמְּקַלֵּל אֶת עַצְמוֹ, וְתוֹלֶה קִלְלָתוֹ בַּחֲבֵירוֹ.
sentences.human_translation: and fight against us, and get him up out of the land” He should have And get us up, Rabbi Abba bar Kahana says: is like a person who curses himself applies his curse to another.
sentences.llm_translation: "And he will fight with us and go up from the land," "and we will go up" - who is it referring to? Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said: Like a person who curses himself, and hangs his curse on his fellow.

sentences.text: ״וַיָּשִׂימוּ עָלָיו שָׂרֵי מִסִּים״, ״עֲלֵיהֶם״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! תָּנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן: מְלַמֵּד שֶׁהֵבִיאוּ מַלְבֵּן וְתָלוּ לוֹ לְפַרְעֹה בְּצַוָּארוֹ, וְכׇל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁאָמַר לָהֶם אִיסְטְנִיס אֲנִי, אָמְרוּ לוֹ: כְּלוּם אִיסְטְנִיס אַתָּה יוֹתֵר מִפַּרְעֹה?
sentences.human_translation: “Therefore they did set over him taskmasters It should have Over them, The school of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, taught: teaches they brought a brick mold and they hung it on the neck of Pharaoh And each and every Jew who said to I am a delicate person [ istenis ] they said to him: Are you at all more of a delicate person than Pharaoh,
sentences.llm_translation: "And they placed over him officers of burdens," "over them" - who is it referring to? It was taught in the school of Rabbi Elazar son of Rabbi Shimon: This teaches that they brought a collar and hung it on Pharaoh's neck, and each and every one of the Israelites who said to them, "I am an officer of burdens," they said to him: Are you more of an officer of burdens than Pharaoh?

sentences.text: ״שָׂרֵי מִסִּים״, דָּבָר שֶׁמֵּשִׂים (לְבֵנִים).
sentences.human_translation: “Taskmasters [ sarei missim ]” A matter that compels [ shemesim ] bricks,
sentences.llm_translation: "Princes of spices," a matter that they use (for) (whitening) (teeth).

sentences.text: ״לְמַעַן עַנּוֹתוֹ בְּסִבְלוֹתָם״, [״עַנּוֹתָם״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ]! לְמַעַן עַנּוֹתוֹ לְפַרְעֹה בְּסִבְלוֹתָם דְּיִשְׂרָאֵל.
sentences.human_translation: “In order to afflict him with their burdens” It should have “In order to afflict them,” in order to afflict Pharaoh, with the burdens of the Jewish people.
sentences.llm_translation: "To afflict him in their burdens," It should have said "their affliction"! To afflict him, to Pharaoh, in their burdens of the children of Israel.

sentences.text: ״וַיִּבֶן עָרֵי מִסְכְּנוֹת לְפַרְעֹה״, רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, חַד אָמַר: שֶׁמְּסַכְּנוֹת אֶת בַּעְלֵיהֶן. וְחַד אָמַר: שֶׁמְּמַסְכְּנוֹת אֶת בַּעְלֵיהֶן, דְּאָמַר מָר: כׇּל הָעוֹסֵק בְּבִנְיָן מִתְמַסְכֵּן.
sentences.human_translation: “And they built for Pharaoh storage cities [ miskenot ], Rav and Shmuel One says that endanger [ mesakenot ] their owners, And one says that impoverishes [ memaskenot ] their owners, as the Master said: All who engage in construction become poor.
sentences.llm_translation: "And he built supply cities for Pharaoh," Rav and Shmuel, one said: that they supplied their husbands. And one said: that they supplied their husbands, as the Master said: anyone who engages in building becomes impoverished.

sentences.text: ״אֶת פִּיתוֹם וְאֶת רַעַמְסֵס״. רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, חַד אָמַר: פִּיתוֹם שְׁמָהּ, וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמָהּ רַעַמְסֵס — שֶׁרִאשׁוֹן רִאשׁוֹן מִתְרוֹסֵס. וְחַד אָמַר: רַעַמְסֵס שְׁמָהּ, וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמָהּ פִּיתוֹם — שֶׁרִאשׁוֹן רִאשׁוֹן פִּי תְהוֹם בּוֹלְעוֹ.
sentences.human_translation: “Pithom and Raamses” Rav and Shmuel One says Pithom its name, and why was it called Raamses? that they collapsed [ mitroses ] one by one And one says Raamses its name, and why was it called Pithom? the opening of the abyss [ pi tehom ] swallowed one by one, and it sunk into the ground.
sentences.llm_translation: "The depths and Ramses." Rav and Shmuel, one said: Its name is "the depths," and why is it called by the name "Ramses" - because it first begins to sink. And one said: Its name is "Ramses," and why is it called by the name "the depths" - because it first begins to swallow the mouth of the deep.

sentences.text: ״וְכַאֲשֶׁר יְעַנּוּ אוֹתוֹ כֵּן יִרְבֶּה וְכֵן יִפְרוֹץ״. ״כֵּן רַבּוּ וְכֵן פָּרְצוּ״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! אָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: רוּחַ הַקֹּדֶשׁ מְבַשַּׂרְתָּן: ״כֵּן יִרְבֶּה וְכֵן יִפְרוֹץ״. ״וַיָּקֻצוּ מִפְּנֵי בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״, מְלַמֵּד שֶׁהָיוּ דּוֹמִין בְּעֵינֵיהֶם כְּקוֹצִים.
sentences.human_translation: “But the more they afflicted him, the more he would multiply and the more he would spread about” It should have The more they multiplied and the more they spread about, Reish Lakish says: Divine inspiration proclaimed to the more he will multiply and the more he will spread about. “And they became disgusted [ vayyakutzu ] due to the children of Israel.” teaches that appeared in their eyes like thorns [ kotzim ].
sentences.llm_translation: "And as he afflicted him, so he multiplied and so he broke forth." "So they increased and so they spread out." What does he want with this? Reish Lakish said: The Holy Spirit proclaims: "So he multiplied and so he broke forth." "And they were loathsome before the children of Israel," teaching that they appeared in their eyes like thorns.

sentences.text: ״וַיַּעֲבִדוּ מִצְרַיִם אֶת בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל
sentences.human_translation: “And the Egyptians made the children of Israel work
sentences.llm_translation: "And they enslaved Egypt the sons of Israel."

sentences.text: בְּפָרֶךְ״, רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אָמַר: בְּפֶה רַךְ. רַבִּי שְׁמוּאֵל בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר: בִּפְרִיכָה.
sentences.human_translation: with rigor [ befarekh ]” Rabbi Elazar says: With a soft mouth [ bifeh rakh ], Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says: With crushing [ bifrikha ],
sentences.llm_translation: In the marketplace, Rabbi Elazar said: with a soft mouth. Rabbi Shmuel bar Nachmani said: with a ripe fig.

sentences.text: ״וַיְמָרְרוּ אֶת חַיֵּיהֶם בַּעֲבֹדָה קָשָׁה בְּחֹמֶר וּבִלְבֵנִים וְגוֹ׳״, אָמַר רָבָא: בַּתְּחִילָּה ״בְּחוֹמֶר וּבִלְבֵנִים״, וּלְבַסּוֹף ״וּבְכׇל עֲבוֹדָה בַּשָּׂדֶה״.
sentences.human_translation: “And they made their lives bitter through hard service, with mortar and brick, Rava says: initially with mortar and bricks, and ultimately “and with every laborious service in the field.”
