And he brings it up
llm_translation: The chamber of the house of Peor: Show us where Moses is buried. If they stood above - it appeared to them as below, if below - it appeared to them as above. They were divided into two groups, those standing above - it appeared to them as below, those below - it appeared to them as above, to fulfill what is said, "And no man knows his burial place."

Rabbi Ḥama son of Rabbi Ḥanina said: Even Moses our teacher does not know where he is buried. It is written here: "And no man knows his burial place," and it is written there: "And this is the blessing with which Moses, the man of God, blessed." And Rabbi Ḥama son of Rabbi Ḥanina said: Why was Moses buried near the house of Pe'or? In order to atone for the incident of Pe'or.

And Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said, "What is the meaning of what is written: 'After the Lord your God shall you walk'? Is it possible for a person to walk after the Divine Presence? Has it not already been stated: 'For the Lord your God is a consuming fire'!"

Talmudic text: Rather, to walk after the attributes of the Holy One, blessed be He: Just as He clothes the naked, as it is written: "And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skin and clothed them" — so too, you should clothe the naked. The Holy One, blessed be He, visited the sick, as it is written: "And the Lord appeared to him by the oaks of Mamre" — so too, you should visit the sick. The Holy One, blessed be He, comforted mourners, as it is written: "And it came to pass after the death of Abraham, that God blessed Isaac his son" — so too, you should comfort mourners. The Holy One, blessed be He, buried the dead, as it is written: "And he buried him in the valley" — so too, you should bury the dead.
"Kotnot Or." Rav and Shmuel, one said: a matter that comes from the skin, and one said: a matter from which the skin benefits.

Rabbi Simlai expounded: The beginning of the Torah is acts of loving-kindness, and its end is acts of loving-kindness. Its beginning is acts of loving-kindness - as it is written: "And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skin and clothed them," and its end is acts of loving-kindness - as it is written: "And he buried him in the valley."

Rabbi Simlai expounded: For what reason did our teacher Moses desire to enter the land of Israel? Was it to eat of its fruit that he needed?! Or to be satiated from its goodness that he needed?! Rather, thus said Moses: Many commandments were commanded to Israel, and they are only fulfilled in the land of Israel. I will enter the land so that they may all be fulfilled through me.

He said to him the Holy One, blessed be He: "Are you seeking anything other than to receive reward? I credit you as if you have done it, as it is said: 'Therefore will I divide him a portion with the great, and he shall divide the spoil with the strong; because he poured out his soul unto death, and was numbered with the transgressors; yet he bore the sin of many, and made intercession for the transgressors.'"

"Therefore I will divide him a portion with the many." Could be like the latter ones and not like the former ones, Scripture says: "And he shall divide the spoil with the strong," like Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who are strong in Torah and commandments. "Because he exposed himself to death," as he delivered himself to death, as it is said: "But if You will not redeem me."

"And for the transgressors he shall be numbered" - that he was counted among the dead of the desert. "And he bore the sin of many" - that he atoned for the incident of the calf. "And for the transgressors he shall intercede" - that he sought mercy for the sinners of Israel that they should repent. And intercession is nothing but prayer, as it is stated: "Therefore do not pray for this people, nor lift up a cry or prayer for them, nor make intercession to Me."
The zealotry upon you for his wife.
He would bring her meal-offering in an Egyptian basket and place it on her hands in order to wave it.
All the meal offerings, their beginning and end are in a sacred vessel, and this is its beginning in an Egyptian bowl, and its end in a sacred vessel.

All meal offerings require oil and frankincense, except this one which does not require either oil or frankincense. All meal offerings come from wheat, except this one which comes from barley. The Omer meal offering, even though it comes from barley, it was brought as a sheaf, while this one is brought as fine flour. Rabban Gamliel says: Just as its preparation is similar to the work of an animal, so too its consumption is food for an animal.

Talmudic text: "Gemara: Tanu Rabbanan, Abba Hanin says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: And why is all this necessary? In order to toil in it, in order for it to be retained. If so, the Torah has mercy on those who transgress His will, all the more so on those who fulfill His will."
And from what is it derived that it is due to anger? Perhaps it is so that the Megillah will not be erased! He holds the opinion
Beverage, and afterwards he brings her meal offering. For if due to the scroll, this is a contradiction to it.

Talmudic text: "All the meal offerings, etc." And they raised a dilemma: The order of meal offerings, how? A person brings a meal offering from within his house in silver and gold baskets, and places it into a service vessel, and sanctifies it in a service vessel, and puts on it its oil and frankincense, and brings it to the priest. And the priest brings it to the altar, and offers it on the northeastern corner opposite the southwestern corner of the altar, and that suffices.

And removes the frankincense to one side, and gathers from the place where its fat has increased and puts it into a service vessel, and sanctifies it in a service vessel. And collects its frankincense and puts it on its back, and brings it up to the top of the altar, and brings it up and burns it in a service vessel, and salts it, and puts it on the top of the wood.
The close part of its handfuls are eaten, and the priests are permitted to put wine, oil, and honey into it, and they are only forbidden from leaven.
It was taught in one place regarding silver vessels and regarding gold vessels! Rav Papa said: Say with vessels fit for service.

From the principle of an Egyptian basket, it is not seen. Like who? — Like one who is not like Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yehuda, as it was taught: Vessels of service made of wood, Rabbi Posa'el and Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yehuda deem them unfit and fit.

Even if you say Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, should we say that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said regarding the important ones, who did he say it regarding? It is not for Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, "Bring him near to your important ones"?!

And she shall place it in the vessels of the service, and sanctify it in the vessels of the service. You heard from it - the vessels of the service only sanctify with intent? Say: She places it in the vessels of the service to sanctify it in the vessels of the service.
And he shall place upon it its oil and its frankincense, as it is stated: "And he shall pour oil upon it and place frankincense upon it."
And he shall bring her to the priest, as it is written: "And he shall bring her to the sons of Aaron, etc."
The Kohen shall bring it near the altar, as it is written: "And he shall bring it near the altar."
He brings it in the south-western corner opposite the corner of the sufficient. Wherefrom -

Talmudic text: It is written: "And this is the law of the meal offering: the sons of Aaron shall offer it before the Lord, in front of the altar." And it was taught: "Before the Lord," one might think to the west — the teaching is necessary to say: "in front of the altar." If not in front of the altar, one might think to the south — the teaching is necessary to say: "before the Lord." How so? One brings it in the southwest corner, opposite the corner of the altar, and it suffices.

Rabbi Elazar says: One might have thought to bring it near to the southwest corner of the altar or to its southeast corner - you say: In any place where you find two verses, one supporting itself and supporting the words of another, and one supporting itself and nullifying the words of another - we leave the one that supports itself and nullifies the other, and we take the one that supports itself and supports the other. When you say "before the Lord" in the west - you nullified "to the front of the altar" in the south, and when you say "to the front of the altar" in the south, you established "before the Lord" in the west. How so? Bring it near to the southeast corner of the altar.
And where was it established? Rav Ashi said: He holds that this Tanna maintains that the entire altar is situated in the north.
What is "vedayo"? Rav Ashei said: It was necessary, for had your mind not said, I would have thought: it requires the offering of its own meal offering, it comes to teach us.

And why not say it like this? The verse says: "And he shall bring it to the priest, etc., and he shall bring it to the altar" - just as bringing near to the priest is with a vessel, so too bringing near to the altar is with a vessel.

And removes its frankincense to one side. So that it should not become crumbled in the hands of the offering, as we learned: If one crumbled and offered in his hand a handful or a pellet of salt or a piece of frankincense - it is invalid.
"And a handful from the place where its fat increased. From where do we derive this? As it is written, 'from its fine flour and from its oil,' 'from its threshing floor and from its oil.'"

And he shall place it into a vessel of service and sanctify it in a vessel of service. Why do I need it? This sanctification is only temporary! For as long as a person is alive; its blood, even though he sanctified it by slaughtering it with a knife on the neck of an animal, he then sanctifies it in a vessel of service, here too it is no different.
"And gathering its frankincense and placing it upon its handful" - as it is written: "And all the frankincense that is upon the meal offering."
And he brings it up.

sentences.text: גַּסְטְרָא שֶׁל בֵּית פְּעוֹר: הַרְאֵנוּ הֵיכָן מֹשֶׁה קָבוּר. עָמְדוּ לְמַעְלָה — נִדְמָה לָהֶם לְמַטָּה, לְמַטָּה — נִדְמָה לָהֶם לְמַעְלָה. נֶחְלְקוּ לִשְׁתֵּי כִיתּוֹת, אוֹתָן שֶׁעוֹמְדִים לְמַעְלָה — נִדְמָה לָהֶן לְמַטָּה, לְמַטָּה — נִדְמָה לָהֶן לְמַעְלָה, לְקַיֵּים מַה שֶּׁנֶּאֱמַר ״וְלֹא יָדַע אִישׁ אֶת קְבֻרָתוֹ״.
sentences.human_translation: the garrison [ gastera ] of Beth Peor Show us where Moses is buried. stood above it appeared to them below below, it appeared to them above. They divided into two groups, those who were standing above, appeared to them below; below, appeared to them to be above, to fulfill that which is stated: “And no man knows of his grave
sentences.llm_translation: The chamber of the house of Peor: Show us where Moses is buried. If they stood above - it appeared to them as below, if below - it appeared to them as above. They were divided into two groups, those standing above - it appeared to them as below, those below - it appeared to them as above, to fulfill what is said, "And no man knows his burial place."

sentences.text: רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא אָמַר: אַף מֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ אֵינוֹ יוֹדֵעַ הֵיכָן קָבוּר. כְּתִיב הָכָא: ״וְלֹא יָדַע אִישׁ אֶת קְבֻרָתוֹ״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם: ״וְזֹאת הַבְּרָכָה אֲשֶׁר בֵּרַךְ מֹשֶׁה אִישׁ הָאֱלֹהִים״. וְאָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: מִפְּנֵי מָה נִקְבַּר מֹשֶׁה אֵצֶל בֵּית פְּעוֹר — כְּדֵי לְכַפֵּר עַל מַעֲשֵׂה פְעוֹר.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: Even Moses our teacher does not know where he is buried. It is written here: “And no man knows of his grave,” and it is written there: “And this is the blessing wherewith Moses the man of God blessed And Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: For what was Moses buried near Beth Peor? In order to atone for the incident Peor
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Ḥama son of Rabbi Ḥanina said: Even Moses our teacher does not know where he is buried. It is written here: "And no man knows his burial place," and it is written there: "And this is the blessing with which Moses, the man of God, blessed." And Rabbi Ḥama son of Rabbi Ḥanina said: Why was Moses buried near the house of Pe'or? In order to atone for the incident of Pe'or.

sentences.text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי חָמָא בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא, מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״אַחֲרֵי ה׳ אֱלֹהֵיכֶם תֵּלֵכוּ״, וְכִי אֶפְשָׁר לוֹ לְאָדָם לְהַלֵּךְ אַחַר שְׁכִינָה? וַהֲלֹא כְּבָר נֶאֱמַר ״כִּי ה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ אֵשׁ אוֹכְלָה הוּא״!
sentences.human_translation: And Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: What is which is written: “After the Lord your God shall you walk, But is it possible for a person to follow the Divine Presence? But hasn’t it already been stated: “For the Lord your God is a devouring fire,
sentences.llm_translation: And Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said, "What is the meaning of what is written: 'After the Lord your God shall you walk'? Is it possible for a person to walk after the Divine Presence? Has it not already been stated: 'For the Lord your God is a consuming fire'!"

sentences.text: אֶלָּא, לְהַלֵּךְ אַחַר מִדּוֹתָיו שֶׁל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: מָה הוּא מַלְבִּישׁ עֲרוּמִּים, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיַּעַשׂ ה׳ אֱלֹהִים לְאָדָם וּלְאִשְׁתּוֹ כׇּתְנוֹת עוֹר וַיַּלְבִּשֵׁם״ — אַף אַתָּה הַלְבֵּשׁ עֲרוּמִּים. הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא בִּיקֵּר חוֹלִים, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֵּרָא אֵלָיו ה׳ בְּאֵלֹנֵי מַמְרֵא״ — אַף אַתָּה בַּקֵּר חוֹלִים. הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא נִיחֵם אֲבֵלִים, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיְהִי אַחֲרֵי מוֹת אַבְרָהָם וַיְבָרֶךְ אֱלֹהִים אֶת יִצְחָק בְּנוֹ״ — אַף אַתָּה נַחֵם אֲבֵלִים. הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא קָבַר מֵתִים, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּקְבֹּר אוֹתוֹ בַּגַּי״ — אַף אַתָּה קְבוֹר מֵתִים.
sentences.human_translation: Rather, that one should follow the attributes of the Holy One, Blessed be He. Just as He clothes the naked, as it is written: “And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skin, and clothed them” so too, you clothe the naked. the Holy One, Blessed be He, visits the sick, as it is written “And the Lord appeared unto him by the terebinths of Mamre” so too, you visit the sick. the Holy One, Blessed be He, consoles mourners, as it is written: “And it came to pass after the death of Abraham, that God blessed Isaac his son” so too, you console mourners. the Holy One, Blessed be He, buried the dead, as it is written: “And he was buried in the valley so too, you bury the dead.
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rather, to walk after the attributes of the Holy One, blessed be He: Just as He clothes the naked, as it is written: "And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skin and clothed them" — so too, you should clothe the naked. The Holy One, blessed be He, visited the sick, as it is written: "And the Lord appeared to him by the oaks of Mamre" — so too, you should visit the sick. The Holy One, blessed be He, comforted mourners, as it is written: "And it came to pass after the death of Abraham, that God blessed Isaac his son" — so too, you should comfort mourners. The Holy One, blessed be He, buried the dead, as it is written: "And he buried him in the valley" — so too, you should bury the dead.

sentences.text: ״כׇּתְנוֹת עוֹר״. רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, חַד אָמַר: דָּבָר הַבָּא מִן הָעוֹר, וְחַד אָמַר: דָּבָר שֶׁהָעוֹר נֶהֱנֶה מִמֶּנּוּ.
sentences.human_translation: garments of skin, Rav and Shmuel One says something that comes from the skin, and one says something from which the skin benefits.
sentences.llm_translation: "Kotnot Or." Rav and Shmuel, one said: a matter that comes from the skin, and one said: a matter from which the skin benefits.

sentences.text: דָּרַשׁ רַבִּי שִׂמְלַאי: תּוֹרָה תְּחִלָּתָהּ גְּמִילוּת חֲסָדִים, וְסוֹפָהּ גְּמִילוּת חֲסָדִים. תְּחִילָּתָהּ גְּמִילוּת חֲסָדִים — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיַּעַשׂ ה׳ אֱלֹהִים לְאָדָם וּלְאִשְׁתּוֹ כׇּתְנוֹת עוֹר וַיַּלְבִּשֵׁם״, וְסוֹפָהּ גְּמִילוּת חֲסָדִים — דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּקְבֹּר אוֹתוֹ בַּגַּי״.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Samlai taught: Torah, its beginning is an act of kindness and its end is an act of kindness. Its beginning is an act of kindness, as it is written: “And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skin, and clothed them” And its end is an act of kindness, as it is written: “And he was buried in the valley
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Simlai expounded: The beginning of the Torah is acts of loving-kindness, and its end is acts of loving-kindness. Its beginning is acts of loving-kindness - as it is written: "And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skin and clothed them," and its end is acts of loving-kindness - as it is written: "And he buried him in the valley."

sentences.text: דָּרַשׁ רַבִּי שִׂמְלַאי: מִפְּנֵי מָה נִתְאַוָּה מֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ לִיכָּנֵס לְאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל? וְכִי לֶאֱכוֹל מִפִּרְיָהּ הוּא צָרִיךְ?! אוֹ לִשְׂבּוֹעַ מִטּוּבָהּ הוּא צָרִיךְ?! אֶלָּא כָּךְ אָמַר מֹשֶׁה: הַרְבֵּה מִצְוֹת נִצְטַוּוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל, וְאֵין מִתְקַיְּימִין אֶלָּא בְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל. אֶכָּנֵס אֲנִי לָאָרֶץ כְּדֵי שֶׁיִּתְקַיְּימוּ כּוּלָּן עַל יָדִי.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Samlai taught: For what did Moses our teacher desire to enter Eretz Yisrael? Did he need to eat of its produce, or did he need to satisfy himself from its goodness? Rather, this Moses said: Many mitzvot were commanded Jewish people, and them can be fulfilled only in Eretz Yisrael, I will enter the land in order that they can all be fulfilled by me.
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Simlai expounded: For what reason did our teacher Moses desire to enter the land of Israel? Was it to eat of its fruit that he needed?! Or to be satiated from its goodness that he needed?! Rather, thus said Moses: Many commandments were commanded to Israel, and they are only fulfilled in the land of Israel. I will enter the land so that they may all be fulfilled through me.

sentences.text: אָמַר לוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא: כְּלוּם אַתָּה מְבַקֵּשׁ אֶלָּא לְקַבֵּל שָׂכָר? מַעֲלֶה אֲנִי עָלֶיךָ כְּאִילּוּ עֲשִׂיתָם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לָכֵן אֲחַלֶּק לוֹ בָרַבִּים וְאֶת עֲצוּמִים יְחַלֵּק שָׁלָל תַּחַת אֲשֶׁר הֶעֱרָה לַמָּוֶת נַפְשׁוֹ וְאֶת פּוֹשְׁעִים נִמְנָה וְהוּא חֵטְא רַבִּים נָשָׂא וְלַפֹּשְׁעִים יַפְגִּיעַ״.
sentences.human_translation: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him: Do you seek for any other than to receive a reward? I will ascribe you as if you had performed them as it is stated: “Therefore will I divide him a portion among the great, and he shall divide the spoil with the mighty; because he bared his soul unto death, and was numbered with the transgressors; yet he bore the sin of many, and made intercession for the transgressors”
sentences.llm_translation: He said to him the Holy One, blessed be He: "Are you seeking anything other than to receive reward? I credit you as if you have done it, as it is said: 'Therefore will I divide him a portion with the great, and he shall divide the spoil with the strong; because he poured out his soul unto death, and was numbered with the transgressors; yet he bore the sin of many, and made intercession for the transgressors.'"

sentences.text: ״לָכֵן אֲחַלֶּק לוֹ בָּרַבִּים״. יָכוֹל כָּאַחֲרוֹנִים וְלֹא כָּרִאשׁוֹנִים, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְאֶת עֲצוּמִים יְחַלֵּק שָׁלָל״, כְּאַבְרָהָם יִצְחָק וְיַעֲקֹב, שֶׁהֵן עֲצוּמִים בַּתּוֹרָה וּבְמִצְוֹת. ״תַּחַת אֲשֶׁר הֶעֱרָה לַמָּוֶת נַפְשׁוֹ״, שֶׁמָּסַר עַצְמוֹ לְמִיתָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאִם אַיִן מְחֵנִי נָא וְגוֹ׳״.
sentences.human_translation: “Therefore will I divide him a portion among the great” might like the later ones and not like the earlier ones, the verse states: “And he shall divide the spoil with the mighty,” like Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who were mighty in Torah and in mitzvot. “Because he bared his soul unto death,” he gave himself over to death as it is stated: and if not, blot me, I pray
sentences.llm_translation: "Therefore I will divide him a portion with the many." Could be like the latter ones and not like the former ones, Scripture says: "And he shall divide the spoil with the strong," like Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who are strong in Torah and commandments. "Because he exposed himself to death," as he delivered himself to death, as it is said: "But if You will not redeem me."

sentences.text: ״וְאֶת פּוֹשְׁעִים נִמְנָה״ — שֶׁנִּמְנָה עִם מֵתֵי מִדְבָּר. ״וְהוּא חֵטְא רַבִּים נָשָׂא״ — שֶׁכִּיפֵּר עַל מַעֲשֵׂה הָעֵגֶל. ״וְלַפֹּשְׁעִים יַפְגִּיעַ״ — שֶׁבִּיקֵּשׁ רַחֲמִים עַל פּוֹשְׁעֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁיַּחְזְרוּ בִּתְשׁוּבָה. וְאֵין פְּגִיעָה אֶלָּא תְּפִלָּה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאַתָּה אַל תִּתְפַּלֵּל בְּעַד הָעָם הַזֶּה וְאַל תִּשָּׂא בַעֲדָם רִנָּה וּתְפִלָּה וְאַל תִּפְגַּע בִּי״.
sentences.human_translation: “And was numbered with the transgressors,” that he was counted among those who died in the desert, “Yet he bore the sin of many,” as he atoned for the incident of the Golden Calf. “And made intercession [ yafgia ] for the transgressors,” as he requested mercy for the sinners of Israel that they should engage in repentance. And pegia nothing other prayer, as it is stated: “Therefore pray not you for this people, neither lift up cry nor prayer for them, neither make intercession [ tifga ] to Me;
sentences.llm_translation: "And for the transgressors he shall be numbered" - that he was counted among the dead of the desert. "And he bore the sin of many" - that he atoned for the incident of the calf. "And for the transgressors he shall intercede" - that he sought mercy for the sinners of Israel that they should repent. And intercession is nothing but prayer, as it is stated: "Therefore do not pray for this people, nor lift up a cry or prayer for them, nor make intercession to Me."

sentences.text: הֲדַרַן עֲלָךְ הַמְקַנֵּא לְאִשְׁתּוֹ
sentences.llm_translation: The zealotry upon you for his wife.

sentences.text: הָיָה מֵבִיא אֶת מִנְחָתָהּ בְּתוֹךְ כְּפִיפָה מִצְרִית וְנוֹתְנָהּ עַל יָדֶיהָ כְּדֵי לְיַגְּעָהּ.
sentences.human_translation: would bring meal-offering in an Egyptian wicker basket and he would place in her hands in order to fatigue her.
sentences.llm_translation: He would bring her meal-offering in an Egyptian basket and place it on her hands in order to wave it.

sentences.text: כׇּל הַמְּנָחוֹת תְּחִילָּתָן וְסוֹפָן בִּכְלִי שָׁרֵת, וְזוֹ תְּחִלָּתָהּ בִּכְפִיפָה מִצְרִית, וְסוֹפָהּ בִּכְלִי שָׁרֵת.
sentences.human_translation: all meal-offerings, their beginnings, and their ends, in a service vessel. But this one, its beginning is in a wicker basket and its end, in a service vessel.
sentences.llm_translation: All the meal offerings, their beginning and end are in a sacred vessel, and this is its beginning in an Egyptian bowl, and its end in a sacred vessel.

sentences.text: כׇּל הַמְּנָחוֹת טְעוּנוֹת שֶׁמֶן וּלְבוֹנָה, וְזוֹ אֵינָהּ טְעוּנָה לֹא שֶׁמֶן וְלֹא לְבוֹנָה. כׇּל הַמְּנָחוֹת בָּאוֹת מִן הַחִטִּין, וְזוֹ בָּאָה מִן הַשְּׂעוֹרִין. מִנְחַת הָעוֹמֶר, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁבָּאָה מִן הַשְּׂעוֹרִין — הִיא הָיְתָה בָּאָה גֶּרֶשׂ, וְזוֹ בָּאָה קֶמַח. רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁמַּעֲשֶׂיהָ מַעֲשֵׂה בְּהֵמָה, כָּךְ קׇרְבָּנָהּ מַאֲכַל בְּהֵמָה.
sentences.human_translation: All meal-offerings require oil and frankincense, and this one requires neither oil nor frankincense. all meal-offerings are brought from wheat, and this one is brought from barley. Although the omer meal-offering brought from barley, it was brought as groats, is brought as flour. Rabban Gamliel says: just as her actions were the actions of an animal, so too her offering is animal food,
sentences.llm_translation: All meal offerings require oil and frankincense, except this one which does not require either oil or frankincense. All meal offerings come from wheat, except this one which comes from barley. The Omer meal offering, even though it comes from barley, it was brought as a sheaf, while this one is brought as fine flour. Rabban Gamliel says: Just as its preparation is similar to the work of an animal, so too its consumption is food for an animal.

sentences.text: גְּמָ׳ תַּנְיָא, אַבָּא חָנִין אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: [וְכׇל כָּךְ לָמָּה —] כְּדֵי לְיַגְּעָהּ, כְּדֵי שֶׁתַּחֲזוֹר בָּהּ. אִם כָּכָה חָסָה תּוֹרָה עַל עוֹבְרֵי רְצוֹנוֹ, קַל וָחוֹמֶר עַל עוֹשֵׂי רְצוֹנוֹ.
sentences.human_translation: It is taught Abba Ḥanin says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: And why so much in order to fatigue her, so that she will retract if the Torah is so protective of those who transgress His will, a fortiori of those who do His will.
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara: Tanu Rabbanan, Abba Hanin says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: And why is all this necessary? In order to toil in it, in order for it to be retained. If so, the Torah has mercy on those who transgress His will, all the more so on those who fulfill His will."

sentences.text: וּמִמַּאי מִשּׁוּם דְּחָסָה הוּא? דִּילְמָא כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלֹא תִּימָּחֵק מְגִילָּה! קָסָבַר
sentences.human_translation: And from where because is protective Perhaps in order that the scroll will not be erased. holds
sentences.llm_translation: And from what is it derived that it is due to anger? Perhaps it is so that the Megillah will not be erased! He holds the opinion

sentences.text: מַשְׁקָהּ, וְאַחַר כָּךְ מַקְרִיב אֶת מִנְחָתָהּ. דְּאִי מִשּׁוּם מְגִילָּה הָא אִימְּחִיקָא לַהּ.
sentences.human_translation: give to drink, and afterward sacrifice her meal-offering. if due to the scroll, it was erased
sentences.llm_translation: Beverage, and afterwards he brings her meal offering. For if due to the scroll, this is a contradiction to it.

sentences.text: כׇּל הַמְּנָחוֹת וְכוּ׳. וּרְמִינְהוּ: סֵדֶר מְנָחוֹת, כֵּיצַד? אָדָם מֵבִיא מִנְחָה מִתּוֹךְ בֵּיתוֹ בִּקְלָתוֹת שֶׁל כֶּסֶף וְשֶׁל זָהָב, וְנוֹתְנָהּ לְתוֹךְ כְּלִי שָׁרֵת, וּמְקַדְּשָׁהּ בִּכְלִי שָׁרֵת, וְנוֹתֵן עָלֶיהָ שַׁמְנָהּ וּלְבוֹנָתָהּ, וּמוֹלִיכָהּ אֵצֶל כֹּהֵן. וְכֹהֵן מוֹלִיכָהּ אֵצֶל מִזְבֵּחַ, וּמַגִּישָׁהּ בְּקֶרֶן דְּרוֹמִית מַעֲרָבִית כְּנֶגֶד חוּדָּהּ שֶׁל קֶרֶן, וְדַיּוֹ.
sentences.human_translation: All meal-offerings, raises a contradiction What is the procedure for meal-offerings? A person brings his meal-offering from his property in baskets [ kelatot ] of silver and of gold, and he places it in a service vessel and sanctifies it in service vessel, and he puts its oil and frankincense on it, and he carries it to the priest. And the priest carries it to the altar and brings it near to the southwest horn opposite the corner of the horn And is sufficient.
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: "All the meal offerings, etc." And they raised a dilemma: The order of meal offerings, how? A person brings a meal offering from within his house in silver and gold baskets, and places it into a service vessel, and sanctifies it in a service vessel, and puts on it its oil and frankincense, and brings it to the priest. And the priest brings it to the altar, and offers it on the northeastern corner opposite the southwestern corner of the altar, and that suffices.

sentences.text: וּמְסַלֵּק אֶת הַלְּבוֹנָה לְצַד אֶחָד, וְקוֹמֵץ מִמָּקוֹם שֶׁנִּתְרַבָּה שַׁמְנָהּ וְנוֹתְנוֹ לְתוֹךְ כְּלִי שָׁרֵת, וּמְקַדְּשׁוֹ בִּכְלִי שָׁרֵת. וּמְלַקֵּט אֶת לְבוֹנָתָהּ וְנוֹתְנָהּ עַל גַּבָּיו, וּמַעֲלֶה אוֹתוֹ לְגַבֵּי מִזְבֵּחַ, וּמַעֲלֵהוּ וּמַקְטִירוֹ בִּכְלִי שָׁרֵת, וּמוֹלְחוֹ, וְנוֹתְנוֹ עַל גַּבֵּי הָאִישִּׁים.
sentences.human_translation: And removes the frankincense to one side, and he removes a handful from the place where its oil has accumulated and he puts into a service vessel and consecrates it in service vessel. And he gathers its frankincense and puts it on top of and brings it up onto the altar. And he brings it up and burns it in service vessel; and he salts it and places it upon the fires.
sentences.llm_translation: And removes the frankincense to one side, and gathers from the place where its fat has increased and puts it into a service vessel, and sanctifies it in a service vessel. And collects its frankincense and puts it on its back, and brings it up to the top of the altar, and brings it up and burns it in a service vessel, and salts it, and puts it on the top of the wood.

sentences.text: קָרַב הַקּוֹמֶץ שְׁיָרֶיהָ נֶאֱכָלִין, וְרַשָּׁאִין הַכֹּהֲנִים לִיתֵּן לְתוֹכָהּ יַיִן וְשֶׁמֶן וּדְבַשׁ, וְאֵין אֲסוּרִין אֶלָּא מִלְּחַמֵּץ.
sentences.human_translation: the handful is sacrificed, the remainders of are eaten. And the priests are permitted to put wine and oil and honey in it, And they are prohibited only from allowing to become leavened.
sentences.llm_translation: The close part of its handfuls are eaten, and the priests are permitted to put wine, oil, and honey into it, and they are only forbidden from leaven.

sentences.text: קָתָנֵי מִיהָא בִּקְלָתוֹת שֶׁל כֶּסֶף וּבִקְלָתוֹת שֶׁל זָהָב! אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: אֵימָא בְּכֵלִים הָרְאוּיִין לִכְלֵי שָׁרֵת.
sentences.human_translation: In any event, teaches in baskets of silver and baskets of gold Rav Pappa said: say in vessels these are suitable to be service vessels
sentences.llm_translation: It was taught in one place regarding silver vessels and regarding gold vessels! Rav Papa said: Say with vessels fit for service.

sentences.text: מִכְּלַל דִּכְפִיפָה מִצְרִית לָא חַזְיָא, כְּמַאן — דְּלָא כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, דְּתַנְיָא: כְּלֵי שָׁרֵת שֶׁעֲשָׂאָן שֶׁל עֵץ, רַבִּי פּוֹסֵל וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַכְשִׁיר.
sentences.human_translation: by inference that an Egyptian wicker basket is not suitable In accordance with whose not in accordance with Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught service vessels that were made of wood, Rabbi deems them unfit, and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, deems them fit.
sentences.llm_translation: From the principle of an Egyptian basket, it is not seen. Like who? — Like one who is not like Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yehuda, as it was taught: Vessels of service made of wood, Rabbi Posa'el and Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Yehuda deem them unfit and fit.

sentences.text: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, אֵימַר דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בַּחֲשׁוּבִין, בִּפְחוּתִין מִי אָמַר? לֵית לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה ״הַקְרִיבֵהוּ נָא לְפֶחָתֶךָ״?!
sentences.human_translation: You even say that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. Say that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says with regard to superior does he say with regard to lesser Doesn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, hold present it now unto your governor,
sentences.llm_translation: Even if you say Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, should we say that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said regarding the important ones, who did he say it regarding? It is not for Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, "Bring him near to your important ones"?!

sentences.text: וְנוֹתְנָהּ לִכְלֵי שָׁרֵת, וּמְקַדְּשָׁהּ בִּכְלִי שָׁרֵת. שָׁמְעַתְּ מִינַּהּ — כְּלִי שָׁרֵת אֵין מְקַדְּשִׁין אֶלָּא מִדַּעַת? אֵימָא: נוֹתְנָהּ בִּכְלִי שָׁרֵת לְקַדְּשָׁהּ בִּכְלִי שָׁרֵת.
sentences.human_translation: He places it in a service vessel and sanctifies it in service vessel. learn from service vessels can sanctify only with intention? Say: He places it in the service vessel to sanctify it in the service vessel.
sentences.llm_translation: And she shall place it in the vessels of the service, and sanctify it in the vessels of the service. You heard from it - the vessels of the service only sanctify with intent? Say: She places it in the vessels of the service to sanctify it in the vessels of the service.

sentences.text: וְנוֹתֵן עָלֶיהָ שַׁמְנָהּ וּלְבוֹנָתָהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְיָצַק עָלֶיהָ שֶׁמֶן וְנָתַן עָלֶיהָ לְבֹנָה״.
sentences.human_translation: puts its oil and frankincense on it. As it is stated: and he shall pour oil upon it, and put frankincense thereon”
sentences.llm_translation: And he shall place upon it its oil and its frankincense, as it is stated: "And he shall pour oil upon it and place frankincense upon it."

sentences.text: וּמוֹלִיכָהּ אֵצֶל כֹּהֵן, דִּכְתִיב: ״וֶהֱבִיאָהּ אֶל בְּנֵי אַהֲרֹן וְגוֹ׳״.
sentences.human_translation: And he carries it to the priest. As it is written: “And he shall bring it to Aaron’s sons,
sentences.llm_translation: And he shall bring her to the priest, as it is written: "And he shall bring her to the sons of Aaron, etc."

sentences.text: וְכֹהֵן מוֹלִיכָהּ אֵצֶל מִזְבֵּחַ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְהִגִּישָׁהּ אֵצֶל הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״.
sentences.human_translation: And the priest carries it to the altar. As it is written: and he shall bring it unto the altar”
sentences.llm_translation: The Kohen shall bring it near the altar, as it is written: "And he shall bring it near the altar."

sentences.text: מַגִּישָׁהּ בְּקֶרֶן דְּרוֹמִית מַעֲרָבִית כְּנֶגֶד חוּדָּהּ שֶׁל קֶרֶן וְדַיּוֹ. מְנָלַן —
sentences.human_translation: brings it near to the southwest horn opposite the corner of the horn. And is sufficient. From where do we
sentences.llm_translation: He brings it in the south-western corner opposite the corner of the sufficient. Wherefrom -

sentences.text: דִּכְתִיב: ״וְזֹאת תּוֹרַת הַמִּנְחָה הַקְרֵב אוֹתָהּ בְּנֵי אַהֲרֹן לִפְנֵי ה׳ אֶל פְּנֵי הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״, וְתַנְיָא: ״לִפְנֵי ה׳״, יָכוֹל בַּמַּעֲרָב — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אֶל פְּנֵי הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״. אִי אֶל פְּנֵי הַמִּזְבֵּחַ, יָכוֹל בַּדָּרוֹם — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לִפְנֵי ה׳״. הָא כֵּיצַד — מַגִּישָׁהּ בְּקֶרֶן דְּרוֹמִית מַעֲרָבִית כְּנֶגֶד חוּדָּהּ שֶׁל קֶרֶן, וְדַיּוֹ.
sentences.human_translation: As it is written: “And this is the law of the meal-offering: The sons of Aaron shall offer it before the Lord in front of the altar” And it is taught “Before the Lord,” might on the western side the verse states: “In front of the altar.” If In front of the altar, might on the southern side. the verse states: “Before the Lord,” How these brings it near to the southwest corner opposite the corner of the horn. And is sufficient.
sentences.llm_translation: Talmudic text: It is written: "And this is the law of the meal offering: the sons of Aaron shall offer it before the Lord, in front of the altar." And it was taught: "Before the Lord," one might think to the west — the teaching is necessary to say: "in front of the altar." If not in front of the altar, one might think to the south — the teaching is necessary to say: "before the Lord." How so? One brings it in the southwest corner, opposite the corner of the altar, and it suffices.

sentences.text: רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר: יָכוֹל יַגִּישֶׁנָּה בְּמַעֲרָבָהּ שֶׁל קֶרֶן אוֹ לִדְרוֹמָהּ שֶׁל קֶרֶן — אָמַרְתָּ: כׇּל מָקוֹם שֶׁאַתָּה מוֹצֵא שְׁנֵי מִקְרָאוֹת, אֶחָד מְקַיֵּים עַצְמוֹ וּמְקַיֵּים דִּבְרֵי חֲבֵירוֹ, וְאֶחָד מְקַיֵּים עַצְמוֹ וּמְבַטֵּל דִּבְרֵי חֲבֵירוֹ — מַנִּיחִין אֶת שֶׁמְּקַיֵּים עַצְמוֹ וּמְבַטֵּל חֲבֵירוֹ, וְתוֹפְסִין אֶת שֶׁמְּקַיֵּים עַצְמוֹ וּמְקַיֵּים חֲבֵירוֹ. כְּשֶׁאַתָּה אוֹמֵר ״לִפְנֵי ה׳״ בַּמַּעֲרָב — בִּטַּלְתָּה ״אֶל פְּנֵי הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״ בַּדָּרוֹם, וּכְשֶׁאַתָּה אוֹמֵר ״אֶל פְּנֵי הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״ בַּדָּרוֹם, קִיַּימְתָּה ״לִפְנֵי ה׳״ בַּמַּעֲרָב. הָא כֵּיצַד? מַגִּישָׁהּ לִדְרוֹמָהּ שֶׁל קֶרֶן.
sentences.human_translation: Rabbi Elazar says might he offers it up on the western side of the corner or on the southern side of the corner. Say: Anywhere you find two verses, one fulfills itself and fulfills the statement of the other, and one fulfills itself and nullifies the statement of the other, leave that fulfills itself and nullifies the other, and seize the one that fulfills itself and fulfills the other. When you say: “Before the Lord,” on the western side, you have nullified “In front of the altar,” on the southern side. But when you say: “In front of the altar,” on the southern side, you have fulfilled: “Before the Lord,” on the western side. How so? He brings it near to the southern side of the corner.
sentences.llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar says: One might have thought to bring it near to the southwest corner of the altar or to its southeast corner - you say: In any place where you find two verses, one supporting itself and supporting the words of another, and one supporting itself and nullifying the words of another - we leave the one that supports itself and nullifies the other, and we take the one that supports itself and supports the other. When you say "before the Lord" in the west - you nullified "to the front of the altar" in the south, and when you say "to the front of the altar" in the south, you established "before the Lord" in the west. How so? Bring it near to the southeast corner of the altar.

sentences.text: וְהֵיכָן קִיַּימְתָּה? אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: קָסָבַר הַאי תַּנָּא כּוּלֵּיהּ מִזְבֵּחַ בְּצָפוֹן קָאֵי.
sentences.human_translation: But where have you fulfilled Rav Ashi said: This tanna holds the entire altar stands in the north
sentences.llm_translation: And where was it established? Rav Ashi said: He holds that this Tanna maintains that the entire altar is situated in the north.

sentences.text: מַאי ״וְדַיּוֹ״? אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: אִיצְטְרִיךְ, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: תִּיבְּעֵי הַגָּשַׁת מִנְחָה גּוּפַהּ, קָמַשְׁמַע לַן.
sentences.human_translation: What And is sufficient? Rav Ashi said: was necessary, enter your mind to say: Require to bring the meal-offering itself near teaches us
sentences.llm_translation: What is "vedayo"? Rav Ashei said: It was necessary, for had your mind not said, I would have thought: it requires the offering of its own meal offering, it comes to teach us.

sentences.text: וְאֵימָא הָכִי נָמֵי? אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְהִקְרִיבָהּ אֶל הַכֹּהֵן וְגוֹ׳ וְהִגִּישָׁהּ אֶל הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״ — מָה הַקְרָבָה אֵצֶל כֹּהֵן בִּכְלִי, אַף הַגָּשָׁה אֵצֶל מִזְבֵּחַ בִּכְלִי.
sentences.human_translation: And say indeed The verse states: and it shall be presented unto the priest, and he shall bring it unto the altar” just as presentation to the priest is in a vessel, so too bringing to the altar in a vessel.
sentences.llm_translation: And why not say it like this? The verse says: "And he shall bring it to the priest, etc., and he shall bring it to the altar" - just as bringing near to the priest is with a vessel, so too bringing near to the altar is with a vessel.

sentences.text: וּמְסַלֵּק אֶת לְבוֹנָתָהּ לְצַד אֶחָד. כִּי הֵיכִי דְּלָא תִּקְּמוֹץ בַּהֲדֵי מִנְחָה, כְּדִתְנַן: קָמַץ וְעָלָה בְּיָדוֹ צְרוֹר אוֹ גַּרְגֵּר מֶלַח אוֹ קוֹרֶט לְבוֹנָה — פָּסוּל.
sentences.human_translation: And he removes its frankincense to one side. in order that not be removed along with the meal-offering As we learned removed handful and a pebble, or a grain of salt, or a crumb [ koret ] of frankincense came out in his hand, it is invalid.
sentences.llm_translation: And removes its frankincense to one side. So that it should not become crumbled in the hands of the offering, as we learned: If one crumbled and offered in his hand a handful or a pellet of salt or a piece of frankincense - it is invalid.

sentences.text: וְקוֹמֵץ מִמָּקוֹם שֶׁנִּתְרַבָּה שַׁמְנָהּ. מְנָלַן? דִּכְתִיב ״מִסׇּלְתָּהּ וּמִשַּׁמְנָהּ״, ״מִגִּרְשָׂהּ וּמִשַּׁמְנָהּ״.
sentences.human_translation: And he removes a handful from the place where its oil has accumulated. From where do we As it is written: of the fine flour thereof, and of the oil thereof” of the groats thereof, and of the oil thereof”
sentences.llm_translation: "And a handful from the place where its fat increased. From where do we derive this? As it is written, 'from its fine flour and from its oil,' 'from its threshing floor and from its oil.'"

sentences.text: וְנוֹתְנוֹ לְתוֹךְ כְּלִי שָׁרֵת וּמְקַדְּשׁוֹ בִּכְלִי שָׁרֵת. לְמָה לִי? הָא קַדְּשַׁהּ חֲדָא זִימְנָא! מִידֵּי דְּהָוֵה אַדָּם; דָּם, אַף עַל גַּב דְּקַדֵּישְׁתֵּיהּ סַכִּין בְּצַוַּאר בְּהֵמָה, הֲדַר מְקַדֵּישׁ לֵיהּ בִּכְלִי שָׁרֵת, הָכָא נָמֵי לָא שְׁנָא.
sentences.human_translation: And he puts into a service vessel and sanctifies it in service vessel. Why do I He has sanctified it once, just as with blood Although the knife sanctifies blood the neck of the animal, sanctifies it again in the service vessel. Here too, it is not different;
sentences.llm_translation: And he shall place it into a vessel of service and sanctify it in a vessel of service. Why do I need it? This sanctification is only temporary! For as long as a person is alive; its blood, even though he sanctified it by slaughtering it with a knife on the neck of an animal, he then sanctifies it in a vessel of service, here too it is no different.

sentences.text: וּמְלַקֵּט אֶת לְבוֹנָתָהּ וְנוֹתְנָהּ עַל גַּבָּיו — דִּכְתִיב: ״וְאֶת כׇּל הַלְּבוֹנָה אֲשֶׁר עַל הַמִּנְחָה״.
sentences.human_translation: And he gathers its frankincense and puts it on top of As it is written: and all the frankincense which is upon the meal-offering”
sentences.llm_translation: "And gathering its frankincense and placing it upon its handful" - as it is written: "And all the frankincense that is upon the meal offering."

sentences.text: וּמַעֲלֵהוּ
sentences.human_translation: And he brings it up
sentences.llm_translation: And he brings it up.

text: שִׁילֹה נוֹב וְגִבְעוֹן וּבֵית עוֹלָמִים.

אִיסִי בֶּן מְנַחֵם אוֹמֵר, אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ: וּמָה בְּטוּמְאָה קַלָּה לֹא חָלַק הַכָּתוּב — בְּטוּמְאַת אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ חֲמוּרָה, לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן? אִם כֵּן מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״בְּקַרְקַע הַמִּשְׁכָּן״ — שֶׁלֹּא יָבִיא מִתּוֹךְ קוּפָּתוֹ.
אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: אֵין שָׁם עָפָר, מַהוּ שֶׁיִּתֵּן אֵפֶר? אַלִּיבָּא דְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, דְּאָמְרִי: לֹא מָצִינוּ אֵפֶר שֶׁקָּרוּי ״עָפָר״.

כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, אַלִּיבָּא דְּבֵית הִלֵּל דְּאָמְרִי: מָצִינוּ אֵפֶר שֶׁקָּרוּי ״עָפָר״, מַאי? אַף עַל גַּב דְּאִיקְּרִי ״עָפָר״, הָכָא ״בְּקַרְקַע הַמִּשְׁכָּן״ כְּתִיב, אוֹ דִילְמָא הַאי ״בְּקַרְקַע הַמִּשְׁכָּן״ לְכִדְאִיסִי בֶּן יְהוּדָה וּלְכִדְאִיסִי בֶּן מְנַחֵם הוּא דְּאָתֵי?
תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: בִּשְׁלֹשָׁה מְקוֹמוֹת הֲלָכָה עוֹקֶבֶת מִקְרָא.
הַתּוֹרָה אָמְרָה בְּ״עָפָר״, וַהֲלָכָה בְּכׇל דָּבָר. הַתּוֹרָה אָמְרָה בְּ״תַעַר״, וַהֲלָכָה בְּכׇל דָּבָר. הַתּוֹרָה אָמְרָה ״סֵפֶר״, וַהֲלָכָה בְּכׇל דָּבָר.
וְאִם אִיתָא — לִיחְשׁוֹב נָמֵי הַאי!

תְּנָא וְשַׁיַּיר. וּמַאי שַׁיַּיר דְּהַאי שַׁיַּיר? שַׁיַּיר מְצוֹרָע, דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְהָיָה בַּיּוֹם הַשְּׁבִיעִי יְגַלַּח אֶת כׇּל שְׂעָרוֹ״ — כְּלָל, ״אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ וְאֶת זְקָנוֹ וְאֵת גַּבֹּת עֵינָיו״ — פְּרָט, ״וְאֶת כָּל שְׂעָרוֹ יְגַלֵּחַ״ — חָזַר וְכָלַל. כְּלָל וּפְרָט וּכְלָל — אִי אַתָּה דָן אֶלָּא כְעֵין הַפְּרָט. מָה פְּרָט מְפוֹרָשׁ: מְקוֹם כִּינּוּס שֵׂעָר וְנִרְאֶה — אַף כׇּל מָקוֹם כִּינּוּס שֵׂעָר וְנִרְאֶה.
מָה רַבִּי — רַבִּי שְׂעַר הָרַגְלַיִם. מַאי מִיעֵט — מִיעֵט דְּבֵית הַשֶּׁחִי וּדְכוּלֵּיהּ גּוּפֵיהּ.

וְהִלְכְתָא: מְגַלֵּחַ כְּדַלַּעַת. דִּתְנַן: בָּא לוֹ לְהַקִּיף אֶת הַמְצוֹרָע — מַעֲבִיר תַּעַר עַל כׇּל בְּשָׂרוֹ, וְקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: וּבַיּוֹם הַשְּׁבִיעִי מְגַלְּחוֹ תִּגְלַחַת שְׁנִיָּה כְּתִגְלַחַת רִאשׁוֹנָה.
אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: כִּי קָא חָשֵׁיב, הֲלָכָה עוֹקֶבֶת מִקְרָא, הָא עוֹקֶבֶת מִדְּרַבָּנַן הִיא.
רַב פָּפָּא אָמַר: כִּי קָא חָשֵׁיב הֲלָכָה עוֹקֶבֶת וְעוֹקֶרֶת, הָא עוֹקֶבֶת וּמוֹסֶפֶת הִיא.
רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: הָא מַתְנִיתָא מַנִּי — רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל הִיא, דְּדָרֵישׁ כְּלָלֵי וּפְרָטֵי.

כְּדַלַּעַת, מַנִּי — רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא הִיא, דְּדָרֵישׁ רִיבּוּיֵי וּמִיעוּטֵי. דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְהָיָה בַּיּוֹם הַשְּׁבִיעִי יְגַלַּח אֶת כׇּל שְׂעָרוֹ״ — רִיבָּה, ״אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ וְאֶת זְקָנוֹ וְאֵת גַּבֹּת עֵינָיו״ — מִיעֵט, ״וְאֶת כָּל שְׂעָרוֹ יְגַלֵּחַ״ — חָזַר וְרִיבָּה. רִיבָּה וּמִיעֵט וְרִיבָּה — רִיבָּה הַכֹּל.
מַאי רִיבָּה — רִיבָּה דְּכוּלֵּיהּ גּוּפֵיהּ, וּמַאי מִיעֵט — מִיעֵט שֵׂיעָר שֶׁבְּתוֹךְ הַחוֹטֶם.
מַאי הָוֵי עֲלַהּ? תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רַב הוּנָא בַּר אָשֵׁי אָמַר רַב: אֵין שָׁם עָפָר — מֵבִיא רַקְבּוּבִית יָרָק, וּמְקַדֵּשׁ.
וְלָא הִיא: רַקְבּוּבִית יָרָק הוּא דַּהֲוַאי עָפָר, אֵפֶר לָא הֲוַאי עָפָר.
כְּדֵי שֶׁיֵּרָאֶה עַל הַמַּיִם. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן, שְׁלֹשָׁה צְרִיכִין שֶׁיֵּרָאוּ: עֲפַר סוֹטָה, וְאֵפֶר פָּרָה, וְרוֹק יְבָמָה. מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אָמְרוּ: אַף דַּם צִפּוֹר.

מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְטָבַל אוֹתָם בְּדַם הַצִּפֹּר וְגוֹ׳״, וְתַנְיָא: ״בְּדַם״, יָכוֹל בַּדָּם וְלֹא בַּמַּיִם — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״בַּמַּיִם״. אִי מַיִם, יָכוֹל בַּמַּיִם וְלֹא בַּדָּם — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״בַּדָּם״. הָא כֵּיצַד? מֵבִיא מַיִם שֶׁדַּם צִיפּוֹר נִיכָּר בָּהֶן, וְכַמָּה — רְבִיעִית.
וְרַבָּנַן: הַהוּא לְגוּפֵיהּ, דְּהָכִי קָאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: אַטְבֵּיל בְּדָם וּבְמַיִם.
וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: אִם כֵּן, לִכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא: ״וְטָבַל בָּהֶם״, ״בְּדַם וּבַמַּיִם״ לְמָה לִי — לְנִיכָּר.
וְרַבָּנַן: אִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״וְטָבַל בָּהֶם״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: הַאי לְחוֹדֵיהּ וְהַאי לְחוֹדֵיהּ, כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא: ״בְּדַם וּבַמַּיִם״ — לְעָרְבָן.
וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, לְעָרְבָן קְרָא אַחֲרִינָא כְּתִיב: ״וְשָׁחַט אֶת הַצִּפֹּר הָאֶחָת וְגוֹ׳״.
וְרַבָּנַן: אִי מֵהָהוּא הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: לִישְׁחֲטֵיהּ סָמוּךְ לְמָנָא וְנִינְקְטִינְהוּ לִוְורִידִין, וּלְקַבְּלֵיהּ לְדָם בְּמָנָא אַחֲרִינָא, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה מֵרַבִּי זֵירָא: גְּדוֹלָה וּמַדְחֵת אֶת הַמַּיִם, קְטַנָּה וְנִדְחֵית מִפְּנֵי הַמַּיִם, מַהוּ?

אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָאו אָמֵינָא לָךְ לָא תַּפֵּיק נַפְשָׁךְ לְבַר מֵהִילְכְתָא, בְּצִפּוֹר דְּרוֹר שִׁיעֲרוּ רַבָּנַן. אֵין לְךָ גְּדוֹלָה שֶׁמַּדְחֵת אֶת הַמַּיִם, וְאֵין לְךָ קְטַנָּה שֶׁנִּדְחֵית מִפְּנֵי הַמַּיִם.
תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הִקְדִּים עָפָר לַמַּיִם — פָּסוּל, וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן מַכְשִׁיר. מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן —

דִּכְתִיב: ״וְלָקְחוּ לַטָּמֵא מֵעֲפַר שְׂרֵיפַת הַחַטָּאת״, וְתַנְיָא, אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן: וְכִי עָפָר הוּא? וַהֲלֹא אֵפֶר הוּא! שִׁינָּה הַכָּתוּב בְּמַשְׁמָעוֹ לָדוּן הֵימֶנּוּ גְּזֵירָה שָׁוָה. נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״עָפָר״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״עָפָר״. מָה לְהַלָּן עָפָר עַל גַּבֵּי מַיִם — אַף כָּאן עָפָר עַל גַּבֵּי מַיִם.
וּמָה כָּאן הִקְדִּים עָפָר לַמַּיִם — כָּשֵׁר, אַף לְהַלָּן הִקְדִּים עָפָר לַמַּיִם — כָּשֵׁר.

וְהָתָם מְנָלַן? תְּרֵי קְרָאֵי כְּתִיבִי. כְּתִיב ״עָלָיו״, אַלְמָא אֵפֶר בְּרֵישָׁא, וּכְתִיב ״מַיִם חַיִּים אֶל כֶּלִי״, אַלְמָא מַיִם בְּרֵישָׁא. הָא כֵּיצַד? רָצָה — זֶה נוֹתֵן, רָצָה — זֶה נוֹתֵן.
וְרַבָּנַן: ״אֶל כֶּלִי״ — דַּוְקָא, ״עָלָיו״ — לְעָרְבָן.
וְאֵימָא: ״עָלָיו״ — דַּוְקָא, ״אֶל כֶּלִי״ — שֶׁתְּהֵא חִיּוּתָן בִּכְלִי!
מָה מָצִינוּ בְּכׇל מָקוֹם מַכְשִׁיר לְמַעְלָה, אַף כָּאן מַכְשִׁיר לְמַעְלָה.
human_translation: Shiloh, Nob, and Gibeon, and the Eternal House,

Isi ben Menaḥem says: There is no need With regard to impurity, a lenient the Torah does not differentiate. with regard to the impurity of a married woman, stringent all the more so not If so, what the verse states: on the floor of the Tabernacle”? that one should not bring from his basket
A dilemma was raised before there is no dust there, what is place ashes no raise the dilemma in accordance with Beit Shammai, as they say: We never find ashes referred to as dust

When you raise the dilemma, in accordance with Beit Hillel, who say: We find ashes referred to as dust What Although referred to as dust, here it is written: “On the floor of the Tabernacle,” Or perhaps “on the floor of the Tabernacle” comes in accordance with Isi ben Yehuda or in accordance with Isi ben Menaḥem.
Come hear that Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: In three instances the halakha supersedes the verse,
The Torah states: in dust” but the halakha is in anything The Torah states razor but the halakha is with anything. The Torah states: bill [ sefer ] but the halakha is on anything
And if it is so consider this as well

taught and omitted What did he omit that he omitted this? He omitted the leper, as it is taught “And it shall be on the seventh day, that he shall shave off all his hair” a generalization. “His head and his beard and his eyebrows,” a detail. “Even all his hair he shall shave off,” then generalized a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization, you may deduce only similar to the detail. Just as the detail is explicitly areas a collection of hair which is visible, so too all areas a collection of hair which is visible
what extend extends pubic hair. What exclude? It excludes armpit hair, and body hair

And the halakha is: shaves like a gourd, As we learned comes to shave the leper, he passes a razor over all of his flesh. And the latter clause, teaches: On the seventh day he shaves The second shaving is like the first shaving.
Rabbi Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: counted halakha supersedes verse. This is supersedes of the Sages.
Rav Pappa said: counted halakha supersedes and uproots This, supersedes and adds.
Rav Ashi said: This baraita , is whose It is Rabbi Yishmael, who interprets generalizations and details.

like a gourd. whose It is Rabbi Akiva, who interprets amplifications and restrictions. As it is taught “And it shall be on the seventh day, that he shall shave off all his hair,” amplification. “His head and his beard and his eyebrows,” restriction. “Even all his hair he shall shave off,” then amplified amplification and restriction and amplification, includes everything.
What does it include? It includes of all of the body. What does it exclude? It excludes nose hairs,
What was about it, Come hear which Rav Huna bar Ashi says Rav says: If there is no dust brings decomposed vegetable and he consecrates
But is not so. Decomposed vegetable is become dust, ashes will not become dust.

so that would be visible upon the water. The Sages taught Three are required to be seen: The dust of the sota the ashes of the heifer and the spittle of a woman whose husband, who has a brother, died childless [ yevama ] In the name of Rabbi Yishmael they said: Even the blood of the bird

What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yishmael? As it is written and dip them in the blood of the slain bird, And it is taught “in the blood,” might in blood and not in water the verse states: “In the water.” If water,” might in water and not in blood the verse states: “In the blood.” How these bring water that the blood of the bird be recognizable within it. And how much a quarter-
And the Rabbis, That for its own as this is what the Merciful One is saying: Dip in blood and in water
And Rabbi Yishmael if so, the Merciful One should have written And dip in them, Why do I in the blood and in the water”? to recognizable
And the Rabbis If the Merciful One had written And dip in them, I would say this separately and that separately. the Merciful One writes: in the blood and in the water,” to mix them
And Rabbi Yishmael mix them Another verse is written: “And he shall slaughter one of the birds
And the Rabbis If from that I would say slaughter adjacent to the vessel and grasp the veins and collect the blood in a different vessel. this teaches us
Rabbi Yirmeya raised a dilemma before Rabbi Zeira: big and effaces the water, small and is effaced due to the water what is

said to him: Haven’t I told you not to take yourself out of the halakha ? The Sages measured with regard to a sparrow. There is no big enough to efface the water, nor is there one small enough to be effaced due to the water.
The Rabbis taught places the dust before the water, unfit; but Rabbi Shimon deems it fit. What is the reasoning of Rabbi Shimon?

as it is written “And for the unclean they shall take of the dust of the burning of the purification from sin, And it is taught Rabbi Shimon said: Is it dust [ afar ] But isn’t it ashes [ efer ]? the Torah altered its usage in order to derive a verbal analogy from it. Dust is stated here, and dust is stated there, Just as there, dust on top of water, so too here, dust, on top of the water.
And just as here, places the dust before the water, it is fit so too there, places the dust before the water, it is fit.

And there, from where do we Two phrases are written It is written “Thereto.” apparently, ashes first. And it is written running water “In a vessel.” Apparently, water first, How these he desires he places it, he desires he places it.
And the Rabbis, “In a vessel,” specifically. “Thereto,” to mix
But say “Thereto” specifically, in a vessel,” that must run into the vessel
Just as we find in every instance facilitating item above so too here, facilitating item above
llm_translation: Shiloh, Nob, and Gibeon, and Beit Olamim.

Issi ben Menachem says, "It is not necessary." And in what case of light impurity did the Scripture not divide? In the case of the severe impurity of a married woman, all the more so? If so, what is the Talmud to say, 'In the ground of the Tabernacle,' - that one should not bring from within his pouch.

He asked them: There is no dust there, so why should one give ashes? According to the opinion of Beit Shammai, it should not be asked of you, for they say: We did not find ashes that are called "dust."

When you inquire, according to the opinion of Beit Hillel who say: "We found ashes referred to as 'dust,' what is the reason? Even though it is called 'dust,' here it is written 'on the ground of the Tabernacle.' Or perhaps this 'on the ground of the Tabernacle' is according to the opinion of Ben Yehuda and according to the opinion of Ben Menachem who come?
Come and hear, for Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: In three places the Halakha follows the verse.

The Torah said "in 'afar' (dust), and the halakha is in every matter. The Torah said "in 'ta'ar' (plowing), and the halakha is in every matter. The Torah said "sefer" (book), and the halakha is in every matter.
And if it is stated - let him consider the matter!

The Tanna says: "And he shall remain." What is the meaning of "he shall remain"? He shall remain as a leper, as it was taught: "And on the seventh day he shall shave off all his hair" - this is a general statement. "His head and his beard and the corners of his eyes" - this is a specification. "And all his hair he shall shave off" - this is a repetition and a general statement. General, specification, and general - you can only judge in a manner similar to the specification. Just as the specification is explicit: a place where hair grows and is visible - so too, every place where hair grows and is visible.
What is "Rabbi"? - Rabbi is the hair of the legs. What is "Mi'eit"? - Mi'eit is the small of the liver and its gallbladder.

Talmudic text: "And the halakha: one shaves like a delaat. As we learned in a Mishnah: If one comes to encircle the metzora, he passes a razor over all his flesh. And it teaches in the latter clause: And on the seventh day, he shaves him a second shaving like the first shaving."
Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak said: When it is being calculated, the halacha follows the interpretation of the verse, as it follows the interpretation of the Rabbis.
Rav Papa said: When a halakha is considered both following and uprooting, it is following and adding.
Rav Ashi said: "Ha matnitah mani - Rabbi Yishmael hi, dedaris k'lalei u'fartei."

Talmudic text: Like a dandelion, count — Rabbi Akiva it is, who expounds the amplifications and the limitations. As it was taught: "And on the seventh day he shall shave off all his hair" — he amplified, "his head, his beard, and the corners of his eyes" — he limited, "and all his hair he shall shave off" — he reverted and amplified. Amplification and limitation and amplification — amplification prevails in all cases.
What is a "Ribah"? - Ribah of all of it is its body, and what is "Mi'et"? - Mi'et is the hair within the nostril.
What is the offering? Come and hear, as Rav Huna son of Ashi said in the name of Rav: If there is no dust there, one should bring a clod of earth and sanctify it.
And not it is: Raqbuvit green he is that was dust, ash not was dust.

Talmudic text: In order that it may be seen upon the water. The Rabbis taught: Three things require to be seen: the dust of the Sotah, and the ashes of the heifer, and the spittle of the yevamah. On account of Rabbi Ishmael they said: Also the blood of a bird.

What is the reason for Rabbi Yishmael's opinion? As it is written: "And he shall dip them in the blood of the bird, etc." And it was taught: "In blood," one might think it refers to blood and not to water - therefore the verse states: "In water." If it is water, one might think it refers to water and not to blood - therefore the verse states: "In blood." How so? One brings water in which the blood of the bird can be recognized, and how much water is needed? A quarter-log.
The sages: that itself, of the body, that thus it says the Merciful One: "Dip in blood and in water."
Rabbi Yishmael: If so, it should have been written: "And he shall dip them," "in blood and in water" - why do I need it? - to distinguish.

The Sages said: If the Merciful One had written "and immerse in them," I would have said: This one for its own immersion and this one for its own immersion, the Merciful One wrote: "with blood and with water" - to mix them.
Rabbi Yishmael, to reconcile a contradiction, another verse is written: "And he shall slaughter the one bird, etc."
The sages said: If from that one, I would say: to slaughter it close to the vessel and weaned it to the young goats, and to receive its blood in another vessel, it is implied to us.
Requested of him Rabbi Yirmeya from Rabbi Zeira: "Large and pushes away the water, small and is pushed away by the water, what is the ruling?"

He said to him: I do not say to you, do not take your life out of the path, in the bird of freedom the sages have said. You have no greatness that you can push away the water, and you have no smallness that you are pushed away because of the water.
The Rabbis taught: If one precedes water with dust - invalid, and Rabbi Shimon permits. What is the reason for Rabbi Shimon's opinion -

Talmudic text: It is written: "And they shall take for the unclean person from the ashes of the burnt sin offering." And it was taught: Rabbi Shimon said: Is it really ashes? Is it not rather dust! The verse has altered its wording to make a comparison. It says here "dust," and it says elsewhere "dust." Just as there it is dust on top of water, so too here it is dust on top of water.
"And what is the case here where one precedes dust to water - it is valid, so too there, where one precedes dust to water - it is valid."

Talmudic text: And there, how do we derive it? Two verses are written. It is written "upon it," implying ashes first, and it is written "living water into a vessel," implying water first. How so? If one desires - this one may place, if one desires - this one may place.
The Sages: "To a vessel" - specifically, "upon it" - to mix.
And why? "Upon him" - specifically, "into a vessel" - that their life should be in a vessel!
What have we found in every place fit for above, so here fit for above.

sentences.text: שִׁילֹה נוֹב וְגִבְעוֹן וּבֵית עוֹלָמִים.
sentences.human_translation: Shiloh, Nob, and Gibeon, and the Eternal House,
sentences.llm_translation: Shiloh, Nob, and Gibeon, and Beit Olamim.

sentences.text: אִיסִי בֶּן מְנַחֵם אוֹמֵר, אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ: וּמָה בְּטוּמְאָה קַלָּה לֹא חָלַק הַכָּתוּב — בְּטוּמְאַת אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ חֲמוּרָה, לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן? אִם כֵּן מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״בְּקַרְקַע הַמִּשְׁכָּן״ — שֶׁלֹּא יָבִיא מִתּוֹךְ קוּפָּתוֹ.
sentences.human_translation: Isi ben Menaḥem says: There is no need With regard to impurity, a lenient the Torah does not differentiate. with regard to the impurity of a married woman, stringent all the more so not If so, what the verse states: on the floor of the Tabernacle”? that one should not bring from his basket
sentences.llm_translation: Issi ben Menachem says, "It is not necessary." And in what case of light impurity did the Scripture not divide? In the case of the severe impurity of a married woman, all the more so? If so, what is the Talmud to say, 'In the ground of the Tabernacle,' - that one should not bring from within his pouch.

sentences.text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: אֵין שָׁם עָפָר, מַהוּ שֶׁיִּתֵּן אֵפֶר? אַלִּיבָּא דְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, דְּאָמְרִי: לֹא מָצִינוּ אֵפֶר שֶׁקָּרוּי ״עָפָר״.
sentences.human_translation: A dilemma was raised before there is no dust there, what is place ashes no raise the dilemma in accordance with Beit Shammai, as they say: We never find ashes referred to as dust
sentences.llm_translation: He asked them: There is no dust there, so why should one give ashes? According to the opinion of Beit Shammai, it should not be asked of you, for they say: We did not find ashes that are called "dust."

sentences.text: כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, אַלִּיבָּא דְּבֵית הִלֵּל דְּאָמְרִי: מָצִינוּ אֵפֶר שֶׁקָּרוּי ״עָפָר״, מַאי? אַף עַל גַּב דְּאִיקְּרִי ״עָפָר״, הָכָא ״בְּקַרְקַע הַמִּשְׁכָּן״ כְּתִיב, אוֹ דִילְמָא הַאי ״בְּקַרְקַע הַמִּשְׁכָּן״ לְכִדְאִיסִי בֶּן יְהוּדָה וּלְכִדְאִיסִי בֶּן מְנַחֵם הוּא דְּאָתֵי?
sentences.human_translation: When you raise the dilemma, in accordance with Beit Hillel, who say: We find ashes referred to as dust What Although referred to as dust, here it is written: “On the floor of the Tabernacle,” Or perhaps “on the floor of the Tabernacle” comes in accordance with Isi ben Yehuda or in accordance with Isi ben Menaḥem.
